<question>



Is America going to have its own version of the NHS now?



and if so how will this impact on the country



</question>



<answer from>



salem
Member since: 21 September 2006
Total points: 2249 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I dont know but i hope we come close to something similar  how will it affect the country i cant even imagine



</answer>



<answer from>



Silke
Member since: 08 October 2006
Total points: 19476 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't know how the NHS is going to survive here with ever growing expectations, ever growing number of cures, ever growing expense, ever growing ageing population, and a budget that is not keeping pace.



Why would they give themselves the same problems?



</answer>



<answer from>



old know all
Member since: 13 April 2006
Total points: 55140 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



In the UK, the NHS takes up 75% of our tax.  In other words, a country like ours with no NHS would need to treble the tax take to pay for it.  Obama has inherited a debt of $10,556,177,748,045.  There's no way America can start to afford a comprehensive heath service.  Expect him to chuck a few million dollars at Medicare, but that will be it.



</answer>



<answer from>



teddy
Member since: 10 July 2007
Total points: 45231 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



i doubt it, most Americans seem to think it would ultimately lead to being a socialist country, and that's not going to happen



for those that knock the NHS let me tell you the truth,



it has problems, the worse currently being its overstaffed by top fat cats, and that the nurses, doctors on the ground are the ones that suffer.  But by and large its the best medical care in the world. You pay into into it, and when its needed its there for you. You don't have to shell out shed loads of money and everyone that complains has no idea of the unholy cost of Private Medical care.  I have had to use both, and believe me i know where my loyalities lie, and its not with overbown private care.  They are just in it for the money.



</answer>



<answer from>



JoelKatz
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 12902 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I hope not. The bigger question is not how it would impact the country but how it would impact the world.



With no market for health care in the United States, there would be no significant market for health care left anywhere in the world. This would mean there is no financial incentive to develop new medical technologies that don't save money. That would be an incredible disaster for the human species.



For example, any technology that allows premature babies who would otherwise die to survive has no cost savings. So why would anyone develop such a technology? There would be no way they could make money on it and the only source of funding would be the very government that would have to shell out money to pay for it.



Today, developing the technology would allow high-end hospitals to pay top dollar for it so they could brag about having the best. Over time, the costs would come down and it would become commonplace. But with no market for health care innovation anywhere, there is basically no conceivable way this could happen.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 635 (Level 2)

<answer from>



Galactic Gobilina

<answer>



Guy Fawkes was an early terrorist. Wasn't it a bit like a Catholic Jihad?



</answer>



<answer from>



kalsflic...
Member since: 10 October 2008
Total points: 1014 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Guy Fawkes was one of a group of conspirators who tried to blow up the House of Lords in 1605 on the day of the State Opening of Parliament . Had they been successful, King James I and members of both the House of Commons and House of Lords would have been killed.



The exact reasons for the Gunpowder Plot are uncertain, but were connected to the struggle between the Protestant and Roman Catholic religions that took place in England during the 16th and 17th Centuries. In any case, the plot was uncovered on November 4th 1605, the night before the State Opening. The conspirators were arrested and tried in Westminster Hall in January 1606 for high treason. All were convicted, and sentenced to death.



November 5th was appointed a day of thanksgiving and is still remembered by bonfire parties and fireworks to this day.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jude
Member since: 20 June 2006
Total points: 16335 (Level 6)



</answer from>

<question from>



subhendu...
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Would you explain me elaborately the procedure of America President Election.?



</question>



<answer from>



redrockc...
Member since: 19 September 2006
Total points: 4620 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, I can tell you this much.  As far as the american people go in the united states, our vote does NOT count when it comes to electing the president of the U.S.  It's all up to the Electorial College votes.  Our vote only counts for local elections.  If they had based the vote on popularity, McCain would have won.



</answer>



<answer from>



krishnam...
Member since: 30 July 2006
Total points: 1479 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Registered voters elects their representatives who in turn elect the president.
Normally the representatives vote for the party to which they represent.
If in a state, majority have voted for a particular candidate, then the vote of the entire state goes to that  candidate.  Example: Ohio - a majority of them have voted for Obama.  Therefore, the entire vote from Ohio  has gone to Obama.



</answer>



<answer from>



NoLibs
Member since: 23 February 2007
Total points: 1227 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I can do it in one word.... BROKEN. An alternative word would be CORRUPTED.



</answer>

<answer>



You most certainly are allowed to ask.  UK does not have a written consitution and there is nothing to stop anyone becoming prime minister, even a complete foreigner, a person who is not even a British citizen can become PM.  But of course none of this can happen until such a person has raised a political party, been elected as an MP then won a general election.



Far more difficult than it all sounds.



The head of state of UK is NOT the prime minister.



The UK head of state is HM Queen Elizabeth II.



Thus if a despot or some other horrid person were to win an election and thus claim to be PM they would first have to go to HM Queen to ask her permission to form a government.  She might very well refuse.



LONG LIVE THE QUEEN

<answer from>



The First Dragon

Total points: 44200 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



General principles for avoiding getting beaten up by a bully:
Never go anyplace where you are alone.  Always make sure somebody else is around.
Always be aware of your surroundings.
Never go home or to school by the same route or at the same time every day.  Vary your schedule.
Act confident.  Don't act worried or scared.
If he does attack you, hit him as many times and as hard as you can.  It doesn't matter who wins the fight; what matters is that you fight back as hard as you can.  He won't come after you again.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sensei Rob
Member since: 19 June 2006
Total points: 3486 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You've got friends right? Get some buddies to watch you're back for you. If this maniac is going to come at you and you're afraid he might be armed then you need someone watching out for him.
It may all be just a way to intimidate you for no reason. Nothing may come from it. But just in case. Keep you back covered and stay around a lot of people. Don't go into the bathroom alone or walk home alone.



Good luck and keep youre eyes open



</answer>

<answer from>



lurker19...
Member since: 05 January 2008

Elections



</answer from>



<answer>



I think that since it's so common for politicians from both countries to steal riffs from each other, that it's only a matter of time.



After all, Reagan in America led to Thatcher in England. Joe Biden actually plagiarised a Tony Blair speech, not even bothering to change key details in the eighties.



The British Obama could be of Indian descent, or more likely a Scotsman. But he will appear.  Hope and Change is something the whole world could use.  And the Men and Women who will bring it are waiting in the wings for their cue.



After all, Slavery was ended in America by a war. In England it was ended by a song--"Amazing Grace."  The Brits, especially the Celts have more experience bringing change with words than us Yanks do.



Edit: Some of the African Americans I know are pretty racist too. But the Irish Americans also provided many of the Community Organizers of the Civil Rights Movement of the 50's and 60's.  And while it's true that rish Americans did riot in 1863 to avoid the Draft, they later fought for, raised equipped, trained and led the Black Regiments.



Celts rarely do anyting halfway. When they are bigots, they are the worst. When they are Statesmen, they are the Best.



Us Yanks have fond memories of an MP from Dublin named Edmund Burke. And nearly half of the Signers of the Declaration of Independence were Celts, 14 Irishmen, a dozen or so Scots and at least one Welshman--fellow by the name of Franklin.



And the words of Jonathan Swift, also from Dublin, are still bringing change throughout the World. Good thing US Republicans mostly haven't read "A Modest Proposal" though. I can just hear them proclaiming, "Wow! What a concept."



</answer>

bogakbri...

</answer from>



<answer>



Consider it this way:  Could it have been the colour?  The black population consists of about 20% of the total US population.  Meaning, if every single black person voted, is 20% of the vote enough to elect someone president?  20% is a good start, but that other 30% has to come from somewhere.



I know when I voted, I did not care about colour.  Obviously, at a minimum 31% of the US agrees with that statement.  I'm not going to say that a few blacks did vote Obama because he's black, but I've also spoken with some blacks who didn't vote Obama because he "was not black enough".



Also, we have had black candidates in the past.  Just like we have had female candidates in the past.  Neither group did well (barring Hillary Clinton).  If it was all about the colour, don't you believe that another black candidate would have done well in a previous election?



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 07 September 2008

<answer from>



Super Ruper
Member since: 21 November 2006
Total points: 21255 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Overall - he deployed sobriety and a somber tone.  From that, he appeared aware of the monumental accomplishment, but more, the task ahead.  It also spoke to the fact that this was just the first step - the work is ahead.



He also focussed on the people - and their vital role....both in the decision - but more importantly, of THEIR role ahead.  He suggested sacrifice, work and servie, and how that will be expected of them if the country is to change and prosper.  He left no doubt that one man cannot change it - they will all need to pitch in.



He also made sure that all bases were covered - his campaign strategists, republicans, troops, international allies, freedom fighters throughout history.  He gave credit where it was due, and included them all in the victory.



Overall - I give him an A+ in his content and delivery.



</answer>

<question from>



portligh...
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How are you helping the forgotten victims of Hurricane Ike?



Did you know that there are many still suffering in the wake of Hurricane Ike?  While the Houston/Galveston area was hit hard by Ike, it truly pales in comparison to the devastation seen on the Bolivar Peninsula and Bridge City Texas.  In Bridge City, a population of over 8000, only 14 homes did not sustain significant damage from Hurricane Ike's massive storm surge.  What have you done to help and can you do more?



Become a part of the Portlight Honor Walk for Gulf Coast Children.  http://www.portlight.org/



See aftermath pictures here... http://www.flickr.com/photos/portlight/



</question>



<answer from>



The Terrible Dr. O'Dwyer
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 141 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



tina turner concert... though the name of the hurricane may bring back painful memories



</answer>



<answer from>



Wonderco...
Member since: 21 January 2008
Total points: 802 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I haven't done anything to help hurricane victims of Ike.



If a great flood comes along and washes away my house and I look sad enough...someone might build me another house.  Just like the one that I was used to.  All cozy and warm and soft.  Then another flood comes along.  Washes all of that away.  Maybe if I look sad again, another person will come along and build me another house.



It's time for me to start building my own house, you see, out of the path of the floods.  It's time for me to rethink the architecture of my home.



I donated money to Katrina victims only to find out much later on that the money never got there...it went to give raises to the people in charge of the "non-profit" organization that I donated to.  If anything trickled down far enough to those intended...it was disbursed on cards and used to buy fur coats and toys.



If I'm going to help a victim I'd like to know that the victim really needs my help, is going to use my donation for something that they truly need, and that 100% of what I'm giving is going directly to the victim and not being pie-cut by an organization using the disaster as an excuse to profit.  ;)



</answer>

Contributing In:



Current Events



</answer from>



<answer>



Judging by your spelling of "color," I assume you are British, or possibly Canadian.  You are right that skin color shouldn't make a difference, but in the US it still does.  Certainly things are much better than they were a hundred years ago, and better even than they were twenty years ago, but it is also true that it has taken 219 years since the founding of the US for a black man to even be a viable candidate for president, much less get elected.



Every time one of these color barriers is crossed -- black generals, black CEOs, black mayors and governors -- we get closer to the day when race will not be an issue, at least not for the vast majority of people in the US.  But if you have read or heard some of the truly hateful, or at the very least ignorant, rhetoric that has been spouted during this campaign, including on this forum, you will understand that race is still a very important issue for many Americans. Now that a black man has been elected to the nation's highest office, and once people see that he can do at least as good a job as other, white presidents have done, we will have gone a long way towards making the US colorblind.  But we are not there yet.



</answer>

<answer>



They were settlers in the 'Happy Valley' area of the Kenyan highlands.  The hedonistic and uninhibited way of life there made conventional relationships irrelevant, and in later years became internationally famous/notorious.  The young Obama was a product of that communal scene, where Europeans, Americans, Greeks, Lebanese and many locals all associated.  It is pointless trying to make observations about his 'biological parents', as this was not an important concept at that time and in that place.



</answer>

<question from>



loanshar...
Member since: 21 April 2006
Total points: 6508 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Horse Racing



</question from>



<question>



What is your opinion on?



the new Provident credit card for use at Argos. In the long term lending criteria of mortgages it would have an APR of 227% That is it is for payment within 6 months. An example on Sky main page is that if you bought a wii for £179.99 you pay back £248.46. Now in the Real world to an average Jo this would represent 72.44% without the calculation that they can reuse the money again. This is still on the high side - BUT - it is designed and sold to the sub-prime market (people who can't get credit anywhere else and often default)
If the whizz kids in the big banks had UNDERSTOOD the prime market then we would not be in the mess we are now.
So why are Sky reporting on it. They have Louis Bond of USwitch saying it shouldn't be seen as anything but a sub prime loan - well Yes! - Could it all be that Ms Bond brought it to their attention knowing that it would be reported as it comes from the NOT so independent company that gets rewarded financially for every switch.
Alongside is details of how to get the cheapest credit cards on USwitch - but - stupidly the ones that get the Provident/Argos card wouldn't get one of them in a month of Sundays.
Isn't it time to kick these so called experts, who are anything but, into touch ?



</question>



<additional details>



Christine H. Maybe if you consider the two stories in the bible, in one Jesus kicked the money lenders out of the Temple the operative part here is "out of the TEMPLE"
The other story is the man who gave three sons money and only one eventually came back giving him profit (bit like the sub prime) the others squandered the money.



Bruntslev. Agree far better to be insular than globalised. (think that is what the arab chappie we don't hear to much about now was against-was is Osama or Abama) As far as working the rates out, that is exactly it they have used a B52 to do the job of a F111. (that aeroplanes) and the sites like uswitch give you a different answer every time but get away with it by putting in a couple of questions that have no revelance.



</additional details>

<question>

A while back a girl in Somalia was gang raped by three men.She and her father reported the incident to the authorities.She was instantly charged with adultery and detained.
A death sentence was handed out as her punishment.The death would be by public stoning.
She was put into a hole and buried up to her neck,so she could not protect her face.A crowd of 1000 people (men and women)gathered for the spectacle,and watched as 50 people (all men) threw stones at her unprotected face.
She cried out for mercy,but the stoning eventually killed her.The girls age???  just 13.This was the price she paid for daring to suggest males might have committed crimes against her.
Humanity at it's lowest ebb.But should our own government be trading and having normal diplomatic relations with barbaric countries.We do not seem to even exert pressure to have sharia law condemned,so they have no need to make changes. http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/...

<answer>



I consider it a duty to take part in the democratic process.  So I personally would like to see compulsory voting to be enforced.  That way we would see political parties elected to government by the real voice of the people, and not just because many of them stayed away from the polling stations giving the winning party an easy and unearned victory.



Such steps would undoubtedly increase the turnout, give the candidates a reason to really earn the votes they do catch and maybe even canvass in a proper fashion to influence those of us who are undecided.



I would love my local candidates to knock on my door and listen to my views, answer a few choice questions, and maybe I could even end up voting for one of them!!



If anyone is still undecided who to place their cross against, they can always put 'none of the above' this would mean even though they hadn't felt confident enough in any of the choices given to vote for them, they have still used their ballot sheet, it will still be counted, and they will, after all have taken part in the democratic process which we all know is a right that has been vigourously  fought for.



That way, who knows, doorstep canvassing may make a welcome return and bring with it a new enthusiasm that is sorely lacking on both sides of the process and most definitely within those chambers of Westminster.



An enthusiasm to get the country back on it's feet and get everybody working to that end.



</answer>

<question from>



John J
Member since: 26 February 2008
Total points: 1248 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



US election - why such huge queues? Why not more voting locations?



Hey US people, why were there such humongous queues of people waiting to vote? I've voted at every UK election (local and national) for 34 years, and every occasion has been the same: I walk in, I get given my voting slip, I go to the voting booth and make my choice, put my ballot paper in the box, and go home. Total time taken? Never more than 2 minutes. And I was peripherally involved with an Australian election once - same story.



So why were there these huge lines of people waiting to vote in the US? Is there some valid reason that there aren't more polling stations to cope with the obvious demand?



I'm just curious - it seems strange when the US is a place where the needs of the customers (i.e. the voters in this case) are always paramount



</question>



<answer from>



Jane
Member since: 14 May 2008
Total points: 3027 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hey, if the Black Panthers can't intimidate voters, what DO we stand for? **** whitey and those who are truly working to pay for welfare. We gotta give those with income under 200K USD a reason to stand out there with baseball bats. Make sure the black man wins and his family gets to slaughter goats and bulls for him. Wow once removed from KENYA, ladies and gentlemen. let's happily welcome OBAMA.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jay D
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 176 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



there where a bunch of first time voters who heard of voting from MTV and thought it would be neato to go vote without understanding anything about anything. The average Obama voter prolly didint know hot to vote seeing as how they have never voted before and there wasn't a LARGE CROWD in the voting booth that they could mindlessly follow. so they got confused and had to figure out something for themselves resulting in the whole process geting backed up =)



</answer>



<answer from>



m_brink
Member since: 19 March 2007
Total points: 61812 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Nintendo Wii



Video & Online Games



Comics & Animation



</answer from>



<answer>



Where I live here in the US, the voting is smooth and quick as well, even this year. But I do live between 2 voting locations that are only about 2 blocks apart (somewhat ironically, both are churches).



Firstly, the people who operate the voting locations are all volunteer (usually senior citizens, since most people have to work election day if they aren't retired), so you can only have as many locations as you can staff. (We really need to change the election day to be either a weekend or a national holiday.)



But there was also the issue that the voter turnout this time far exceeded past elections, even with a large number of people taking advantage of loosened rules on voting early. We are the laughingstock of most democracies for our ridiculously low voter turnout at around 50%, but this time, it looks like it spiked up about another 10% over the 2004 Presidential election.



</answer>



<answer from>



lemony_f...
Member since: 26 July 2008
Total points: 653 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



thats exactly what i was thinking



</answer>

<additional details>



See i thought it might be his health care plans but if conservatives weren't so blinded by the fear or the 'reds' then they would see that America is one of the only developed nations that doesn't have a public health care scheme. Me have medicare here in Australia and people aren't shouting 'comrade' on  the streets just yet! XD



I totally agree 'its that guy'. Also the negative connotation that goes along with socialism is a little unwarranted. Sure Socialist governments have done bad things but so have "democratic" governments.Socialism works better in some countries than others, just the same as democracies work better in some than others. Its sad that politicians have created such a fear of ideologies that aren't their own. I'm not saying I support socialism, far from it, but i don't seen why it has to be used as an offensive term.

<answer from>



It's That Guy
Member since: 07 December 2007
Total points: 42184 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Elections



</answer from>



<answer>



There's a rule for Republicans.  If you dislike someone, or you disagree with him, then it's okay to call him any bad word you can think of.  It doesn't matter if it's true or not.  You can even make up lies about him and repeat them over and over, long after they've been discredited.



For years and years, Republicans used the word 'liberal' to mean anything they didnt like.  So Hitler was a liberal, Stalin and Mao and Pol Pot were liberals.  And Bill Clinton was a liberal, so the suggestion was that he was no better than the others.  Newt Gingrich, when he was Speaker of the House, said Bill Clinton was the most liberal president in the history of the US.  You would expect better from a guy with a PhD in American History!  All he really meant was only that he didn't like Clinton.



Well after that the word 'liberal' was sort of worn out.  It came to mean nothing at all. So now they use the word 'socialist'.  Anyone who would call Obama a socialist is showing that either they know nothing about Obama or that the don't really know what -socialism- is.  It's just a bad word, and they don't like him, so he must be one.



</answer>



<answer from>



Neil
Member since: 16 November 2006
Total points: 6515 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Americans are much more averse to paying taxes than most other nations.



The fact that the U.S. Army with all its hardware is paid for out of taxation seems alien too them, they would sooner spend their free time reducing their tax bill (and paying specialised lawyers to help them) than actually enjoying their life.



So when something like universal heath care is proposed the people who have a comfortable life start taring it with words like socialism, because they will have to pay some more tax to fund it.



What they do not realise is that they will save on the sky high medical insurance rates they have to pay now, which incidentally does not fund their care 'indefinitely' but only for a certain period.



A 'socialist' heath care programme funds treatment as long as you require it.



They also don't realise that socialism is a democratic choice, people can and do vote for socialism democratically, and they also vote it out. There is a vast difference between democratic socialism and one party state communism, but many right wing Americans are blinkered in their hatred for anything other than their own views.



</answer>

<answer>



Ethnocentrism has sociobiological origins and therefore, sadly, will always we with us. However this backward part of our nature has taken a royal trashing with the election of Barack Obama. It is possible that the election of the first african-american will be a watershed in the general publics conscious, at least partially eclipsing raciest tendencies.



Regarding money. I would certainly say that money helped Obama a lot. But I would not say it was 'money-power as usual'. After all, the money Obama spent was not from usual sources. It was from small individual contributions online. He opted out of a broken system. McCain was meant to be constrained by the 83 million dollars in public financing. Was he? No, he spent over 250 million. That is why the system is broken. Obama choose the ethical decision to opt out of the system and this gave him an advantage. 'Ethical' therefore not 'power-as-usual', a phrase synonymous with corruption.



</answer>

<question from>



Haydon
Member since: 09 April 2008
Total points: 313 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Why were rural voters more likely to vote Republican?



Example: Check-out Ohio, who voted for Obama yesterday. The states rural areas (which make up the majority of Ohio's area) all voted for McCain. It was a sea of red. Only the cities voted for Obama. Why? This is a trend in all states, but especially the battleground states. Are the rural voters minds different? If so, in what way? What made living in a city change people to identify with more Obama? Why are cities blue and rural areas red?



</question>



<answer from>



Miss England
Member since: 21 June 2008
Total points: 2810 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Im not saying I am an expert on American politics but the more rural areas are very sheltered from the world as a whole, they don't have the cosmopolitan impetus larger cities have and are wrapped in cotton wool with a very narrow view of the world..well done to you all for voting in a man with change on his mind.



Source(s):



A Brit who has lived in both California and Arizona



</answer>



<answer from>



nic_42_0...
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 829 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



In less cosmopolitan areas, people tend to be more socially conservative and less progressive; they prefer an older president, they value military experience above higher education.



The cultural issues that concern them are Republican wedge issues, such as abortion and gun rights. They also tend to be slightly more territorial and concerned with maintaining their property and culture against other influences and/or government intervention.



In cities, the population tends to be more ethnically diverse, secular, educated and progressive.



</answer>



<answer from>



giginotg...
Member since: 05 November 2007
Total points: 6073 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is about their economic structure.



In rural area, most likely they are relating to raw material or food products. There is little about credit markets. In their mind, the most important jobs is to get rich people to buy their products. It is their desire to drive the economy in cities again.



Of course, this would be similar to the depression period in 1920s.



If Obama can make use that force, change would be possible. For example, Obama government should create projects in infrastructure area such as rebuild bridges, electric grib, fibre optic covering the whole U.S. In fact, a lot of facilities in U.S. are totally outdated. By doing so, he can create jobs and properly consume those exceeding raw material inventry.



He can do so by create loans to all companies at that area and they need to return part of their gain to government.



</answer>



<answer from>



Gonsta
Member since: 15 October 2008
Total points: 370 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you take a look at the bible belt it was a  wash with Red during the election voting summary's on the networks.
They support many right wing views that are shoved down our throats by the republicans, such as supporting the war, anti gay, right to life anti abortionists, right to arms to name a few.
In city's you are more likely to adopt different views due to living in closer vicinities to diverse cultures from a wider range of migrants and visitors from various country's, and more than likely discover that they aren't that different than you or me.

<additional details>

<answer from>



kwaaikat
Member since: 08 February 2007
Total points: 2906 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Honestly I can see very little semblance between Blair and Obama. Presidential (or priministerial, in the case of the UK) generally try to be all things to all people in their campaigns. In order to win in the US (or in most countries), one needs to appeal to many different people.



Yes Obama may well disappoint some of the electorate. Given his relatively big win from non-traditional democrats, that is not unlikely. It seems some "Republican voters" are giving him a chance, because of the desperate times. At the same time, if he pulls of a good economic recovery (and face it, the US as at a low base right now) then Obama may end up being remembered as one of the most popular presidents in recent times.



</answer>

<answer>



Your question is absurd.



It's a myth spread by the ignorant that Blair was elected on a wave of euphoria.



Actually he was elected on an average percentage of a low turnout the first time round and had gained the nickname 'Tony Blur' before even winning in 1997.



He managed to gain sky-high approval ratings soon after election by making friends with tabloid editors (and Rupert Murdoch). If anything it shows the idiocy of the British public that they were so influenced by the propaganda spread by the likes of The Sun in Blair's first year.



Obama is a much more intelligent and substantial politician.

<question from>

<question>



At last count how many cities are burning?



</question>



<additional details>



You know.  To celebrate the victory.



</additional details>



<answer from>



patticha...
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 17615 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I was wondering the same thing. I assumed there would be similar activity to protest a loss OR celebrate a victory. Any reason to burn down your city works!

<question>



HIV Cases in U.S. Higher than Thought as new test method can tell how recent infection, esp less than 5 mths??



HIV Cases in U.S. Higher than Thought
By Mike Stobbe

August 3, 2008



http://www.CBNNews.com - ATLANTA - The number of Americans infected by the AIDS virus each year is much higher than the government has been estimating, US health officials reported Sunday, acknowledging that their numbers have understated the level of the epidemic.

The country had roughly 56,300 new HIV infections in 2006 -- a dramatic increase from the 40,000 annual estimate used for the last dozen years. The new figure is due to a better blood test and new statistical methods, and not a worsening of the epidemic, officials said.

But it likely will refocus US attention from the effect of AIDS overseas to what the disease is doing to this country, said public health researchers and officials.

"This is the biggest news for public health and HIV/AIDS that we've had in a while," said Julie Scofield, executive director of the National Alliance of State and Territorial AIDS Directors.

More Aggressive Testing

Experts in the field, advocates and a former surgeon general called for more aggressive testing and other prevention efforts, noting that spending on preventing HIV has been flat for seven years.

The revised estimate by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the methodology behind it were to be presented Sunday, the opening day of the international AIDS conference in Mexico City.

Since AIDS first surfaced in 1981, health officials have struggled to estimate how many people are infected each year. It can take a decade or more for an infection to cause symptoms and illness.

One expert likened the new estimate to adding a good speedometer to a car. Scientists had a good general idea of where the epidemic was going; this provides a better understanding of how fast it's moving right now.

"This puts a key part of the dashboard in place," said the expert, David Holtgrave of Johns Hopkins University.

Based on the new calculations, officials believe annual HIV infections have been hovering around 55,000 for several years.

"This is the most reliable estimate we've had since the beginning of the epidemic," said Dr. Julie Gerberding, the CDC's director. She said other countries may adopt the agency's methodology.

1.1 Million Americans with AIDS Virus

According to current estimates, around 1.1 million Americans are living with the AIDS virus. Officials plan to update that number with the new calculations, but don't think it will change dramatically, a CDC spokeswoman said.

The new infection estimate is based on a blood test that for the first time can tell how recently an HIV infection occurred.

Past tests could only detect the presence of HIV, so determining which year an infection took place was guesswork -- guesswork upon which the old 40,000 estimate was based.

The new estimate relies on blood tests from 22 states in which health officials have been using a new HIV testing method that can distinguish infections that occurred within the last five months from those that were older.

How many cases are thru summer drunkenness/doping up?

Whose policies are more likely to encourage a sensible sexual revolution, a moral renewal before Christmas party season peak?

<answer from>



S.A.M.
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 574 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Read the article you quoted and you will discover the satellite system is Ukraine's to give, not Russia's.  When Ukraine became an independent nation after the USSR's collapse, Ukraine became a major military power in the global scope. Not only did they become the owner of this satellite system, which Ukraine companies designed and implemented, but they also became the 3rd largest nuclear power in the world. While the nuclear missiles were returned to Russia to be deactivated, all other military systems remained in place.

Ukraine desperately wants from beneath the thumb of Russia, from both their threats and economic influence on their way of life. Ukraine is a viable economic power of eastern Europe providing much of the region's agricultural and raw steel imports.



If this military grade satellite system is an legitimate offer by the Ukraine government, the west would be foolish not to accept it.  Only to accept the offer of satellite access and not provide an umbrella of military protection to Ukraine from a future Russian attack would make us of an lower morality than that of the current Russian regime.

In February 2008, Ukraine was added to Russia's growing list of countries threatened with nuclear retaliation. Russia is the bully in the democratic neighborhood, a supporter of further Cold War type actions.

Western media outlets accuse the American leadership of reinitiating the Cold War but what western government has threatened Russia with nuclear annihilation?

http://www.nti.org/e_research/profiles/U...
http://www.missilethreat.com/archives/id...
http://www.spacewar.com/reports/Ukraine_...
http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/w...



</answer>

wampum15

<answer>



The US is a newer country and was developed around the automobile. The UK's infrastructure was set in motion long before the auto came into being. Here, we generally have to travel greater distances due to sprawling suburbs and more decentralized development. We've been spoiled with relatively low petrol prices over the years mainly due to our cozy relationship with the monarchs of middle eastern oil producing countries.

<answer from>



Lorelei
Member since: 12 June 2007
Total points: 8132 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I see both sides of the story being American and living in Europe. I think the biggest problem is that America has no where near the same public transportation system as Europe.
I grew up in a small town in the USA and if you didn't have a car then you were out of luck. There was no taxi to call, no bus, no train, no tramway, etc. You had your car and that was that.
Bigger cities are probably not as impacted by the higher fuel costs than rural towns. People from these towns often have to drive to the bigger cities to get to their places of work or to grocery stores, etc.
My father still lives in the small town I grew up in and he says he can't afford to drive any other place except to work and back. If he did drive more than than then he wouldn't be able to afford to have a place to live, food to eat, heat, electricity, so on and so forth. 
Back when fuel prices were cheaper, America was known for having huge gas guzzling cars because they could afford them! More and more now though you are seeing people trade in their cars for smaller and better fuel efficient autos. I saw an article the other day on Yahoo that said the Smart car has a waiting list 10 months long in the USA.
Even more kids are starting to ride their bicycles to school. Long gone are the days of 16 year olds getting their license and very first car, they can't afford it. Instead, they are riding their bikes. 
I can't speak for the UK, because I don't live in that part of Europe but, I do know that where I live rent and grocery shopping is significantly cheaper than America. Also, a lot of apartments (flats) include heating, electricity, and water. My parents have to pay for each one of those things separately.
They heat with oil. My father was almost unsure that they could afford enough oil to last the winter. They were literally faced with the question of whether they should heat or eat? 
In the moment, I am definitely glad that I live in Europe where you can survive quite comfortably on a single income. I hope it gets better for America, I really do.



</answer>



<answer from>



Elliot Ness
Member since: 04 July 2006
Total points: 9228 (Level 5)

<question>



Should the Japanese whaling ship be bombed?



The Nisshan Maru, a Japanese whaling ship, is on fire off the coast of Antarctica.  There is estimated to be over 1,000 tons of fuel - as well as other chemicals, which could be highly dangerous to the environment there.



When the Torrey Canyon ran aground off the coast of Britain in the '60,s  the Navy and RAF bombed it before too much damage to the environment could be done.



Should the Japanese ship, which has no crew on board and has serious fires, be bombed before it is too late?



</question>



<answer from>



Snowraid...
Member since: 16 November 2006
Total points: 4408 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yes it needs to be treated like the Torrey Canyon and bombed immediately to save the environment. This must be carried out by the government whose waters it is in with the consent of the Japanese otherwise war could break out. This is a dire emergency. Let this be a lesson as to what can happen when any such contentious behaviour (whaling) takes place.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Glad someone appreciates the urgency.  To answer an answer, floating pontoons are put round the ship to stop the spread of oil, then when the ship sinks, the oil is contained and cleaned up.



</asker's comment>

<question>



Muslim separatists who have threatened Beijing do Deadly Attack in China Days B4 Olympics: cover-up reports ??



By Charles Hutzler

August 4



http://CBNNews.com - BEIJING

Attackers rammed a dump truck into a patrol station in China's restive Central Asian border province Monday morning, tossing grenades in a raid that killed 16 officers and wounded others, the state-run Xinhua News Agency reported.

The attack in Xinjiang province was in an area where local Muslims have waged a sporadic rebellion against Chinese rule.

It came just four days before the start of the Beijing Olympics - an event that at least one radical Muslim group has vowed to attack.

CBN NEWS SUMMER OLYMPIC COVERAGE:
Beijing Olympics 2008

CBN News Sr. Reporter George Thomas' Latest Video Blog from Beijing

CHINA CONNECTION:
Beijing Welcomes Me

Aerial Tour of Beijing



The brief Xinhua account said the attackers drove the dump truck to get inside the paramilitary police compound in the Kashgar area and then exploded two grenades.



A state television report gave a different version, saying the police were attacked while marching in front of a hotel while conducting morning drills.



SO - how reliable are Govt safety 'assurances' ??

Just a few points about Western's obsession of criticizing human rights in China:

The only reason Westerners keep harping on human rights in China is because it’s the only thing they can still latch onto to make themselves feel superior and smug about their triumph over China.

Westerners see the writing on the wall. Compared to Asia, they’re losing the race in terms of:

- economic growth
- educational quality
- technological innovation
- environmental investment (China invests way more than the U.S. does toward sustainable energy research)
- and hipness (Asia has stopped looking to the U.S. for the next cool trend. Now Asians are increasingly seeing South Korea as the top trendsetter, whether in terms of TV, film, fashion or music.)

China is just a convenient proxy for rising Asian dominance.

If Americans really cared about human rights abroad, they would have started making noise about China 30 years ago. And they’d be making noise about just about most countries in South America, Africa and the Middle East.

But none of those countries are an economic or military rival to the U.S./Europe, are they?

<question>



The torture of Kevin Davies...?



http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk...
Kevin was tied up in a shed and tortured for over four months until his body eventually gave up and he died in  2006.



During his imprisonment he was beaten several times a day, branded with a hot knife and burnt with some kind of corrosive liquid.  He was found with 10% burns, bruises and fractures all over his body including his ribs and larynx.
At the autopsy they discovered that the only thing he had eaten in 3 days were potato and carrot peelings.



3 people were originally charged with his murder but Kevin was an epileptic, and as they couldn't determine whether the epilepsy played a part in his death the charges were dropped.  They were locked up on various charges for 10 years each but will only serve half that and are due for release in 2011.

His family are desperately trying to overturn this ruling and have started a petition online.

I was horrified to read his story in in my friends copy of Take a break magazine this morning and felt that I had to do something about it.

Please sign the petition...

http://www.petitiononline.com/SRpet1/pet...



</question>

<question>



What does the Russia-Georgia mean to the UK?

</question>



<answer from>



Dame Violetta - KING REX TO WIN!
Member since: 20 July 2007
Total points: 2400 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Storm in a tea cup, stirred by the media.. not even headline news today. Russia did NOT threaten to Nuke Poland, a general said if Poland had a missile defence system on it soil, it would be the first target in any conflict.. harsh but true. The media reported it out of context and "sexed" it up to make headlines. 
Most European leaders know that Georgia bit off more than it could chew and got a dressing down from Russia. End of.



</answer>

<question>



Is freedom of speech dead on y answers?.



iposted a legitimate question on why can we believe in religion and the question was removed , it raised valid issues but it seems youcan question any thing except religion., is this the achilles heel of this site and is it of any use if valid questions are to be censored. p.s. i do respect every bodys right to follow any religion they wish to.



</question>



<additional details>



in retrospect i think we should all post questions on subjects we all agree on (if thats possible) and then all go and play with the bunny wunnies in the land of green ginger so we dont upset religious believers when they suddenly realise that all religions might be a sham and believing in themselves or something more tangible might be risky!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Clairei
Member since: 27 July 2006
Total points: 773 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It does seem that a lot of religion based questions get removed, but then I guess they have their terms and conditions to follow as well as a team of Lawyers who helped set them up! I have also seen a lot of ok looking sex based questions removed too, whereas others which are very explicit are left on, so there's no saying what they'll remove. People are very scared at present of causing offence and inflaming unstable people, and I expect Yahoo don't want to get dragged into a row. I do agree though that it's a shame in a way, although you can argue forever about religion and never get anywhere.
Personally, although I was brought up as a Catholic, I view religion as the cause of most trouble in the world. I prefer now to be 'spiritual not religious'. I don't follow rules made up by other humans, I just try to do the right thing (I have to say too that I don't know any religious people who are actually nice).



</answer>

<answer from>



anotherb...
Member since: 13 April 2007
Total points: 5399 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I did my A levels in 1989.

I recently took a look at the A level math papers from then, now and somewhere in the middle and tried to do them.

The older papers were definitely harder. The current ones appeared to lead much more. There wasn't really a need to string together more than one solution to get to the end of a problem, because it led you every step of the way.

So in my unscientific study, yes, A levels are getting easy these days.

---

For the unintiated, A levels are "Advanced Level" exams that British schoolchildred take prior to entering college. It generally serves as the exams you have to pass to get a place in college.

Typically (back in the day) you did three. The course took 2 years between ages 16 and 18. Taking 4 was for the swatty spods.

These days this is still true but there are a bunch more options, AS levels and other things.  People seem to be able to take more of them. There is controversy as to whether they have become easier over the years.



</answer>



<answer from>



Joanne C
Member since: 16 May 2008
Total points: 152 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I really don`t know. All i know is that the standard of english has certainly deteriorated. Obviously, there are still younger people who can spell and write well. But, it seems to be the minority. I haven`t sat an exam for years, so it is hard for me to judge. :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Beastie
Member since: 30 March 2006
Total points: 9798 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



What I've noticed is that teaching gets tinkered with, year in, year out. This is supposedly to improve the teaching.
But instead of saying that it's apparent these changes work when scholars pass more exams, people say that it's because the exams are simpler.

Frankly, it sounds like utter bollocks to me.



If someone can tell me, with a reasonable explanation, what real interest an examination authority would have in simplifying exams, I'd love to know.

I don't believe A levels are getting easier. I believe most teachers are more competent than those who like to knock them would want us to believe.

<answer>



I feel that as a nation we are becoming more intelligently inclined.

Whether this is down to brain power or computer power, I am not sure.

When I went to school, if you took a calculator with you, it got confiscated. Now you can get detention for not taking one (or so I understand from a 12 year old)

The more we learn about the world we live in, the more we have to teach our youngsters, so maybe more computer power adds to more brain power. The way we learn, in my opinion has not changed over the years, we just do it from different angles.

I currently study quantum mechanics, and without computers I would need to live to be 200 to understand it. However, without computers, the subject would not exist.

I say let teachers teach, pupils learn, and politicians keep their noses out.



</answer>

james d

Total points: 913 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



my view is that to say that they are becoming easier is putting down students who do work hard and deserve to get good grades

however having said that, the government has an agenda to make more people pass with good grades and get them into tertiary education, so you see a huge increase in the percentage in top grades as compared to say 18 years ago when i did my a-levels - and i;m sorry but i dont believe that people are smarter now than they were then (conversely i dont think that they are less intelligent either)

what they should do (and what I always thought they did) is appoint the top percentile with an A, the next with a B and so on - and keep these percentiles constant over time, so if you receive an A - you can say with pride that you are in the top ten percent for that subject and that is a statistic that employers can understand and equate to.

Unfortunately if you award everyone with top grades and a university education - which seems to be the government policy of inclusivity and not wanting anyone to feel a loser, the whole system is totally devalued.

Which ultimately - is unfair on you as an A level student, because I dont doubt that you do work very hard



</answer>

<answer from>



james d
Member since: 24 August 2007
Total points: 899 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i always find it amazing that creationists are outraged by the thought they evolved from apes, but think the idea that they were created from dust is far more acceptable and believable (thats what the bible says, ashes to ashes, dust to dust)

can evolution be proved, it may be flawed - but look up 'microevolution' which supports the theory, evolution is based on the principal that within any population, there are a small number of abnormal mutations and if these mutations are somehow beneficial, these mutations will be passed on to the next generation, if you can physically seperate populations to prevent interbreeding, then these populations will evolve seperately according to the environmental pressures placed upon it.

there was an experiment conducted where they took seedlings frm a relatively neutral saline salt environment and replanted them across the world in a range of different salinities - those that could not 'cope' died, but the surviving seedlings that could cope with high salinity passed on their genes which code for that ability - so within a few generations, the entire population in that environment had adapted to live in high saline conditions, similarly with  other environmental pressures.

The Spartans has a theory that all children should be placed out in teh cold - the weak ones would die so the surviving ones would be strong warriors - survival of the fittest



ok i am an athiest so you may say that I am biased, but evolution at least has some proof and makes logical sense, you may look at the body and say it is a miracle, but given infinite time surely infinite possibilities are possible infinitely



Source(s):



a PHD education including population genetics



</answer>

<answer>



Interesting question Neglect can come in many forms and degrees  Depriving a child of food and water and shelter. Leaving a child alone for long periods of time. Sexual neglect. I would guess that the little 6 year old is not being fed and this must be reported to social services ASAP.Never feel bad by reporting Its far better to be wrong than let the neglect to continue. That child needs help NOW. She could be in grave danger by knocking on doors where a paedophile may live.

<answer from>



spegali
Member since: 01 September 2007
Total points: 2561 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The neighbourhood I work in is very poor. The scenario you talk about actually happened a few years ago. One of the parents came into school to ask what she should do, she had seen one of the pupils begging at doors for food. The girl was 10 and had a brother of 8 and had a baby sister. School contacted Social Services, they visited the family. They found the single mother was an alcoholic, incapable of looking after her children, the eldest daughter was trying to see to everything.The children were removed and help was found for the mother. All the children returned after mum managed to get back on track.

It is very difficult to get a child removed from its parents. It is quite rightly a very last resort, social services will move heaven and earth to keep families together by providing all sorts of help. I work with some families that have had social service involvement for years and there are cases were I wish they would remove the children as they are condemned to following in the feckless parents footsteps.



</answer>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



Would you like to live to 113?



The worlds oldest man celebrates his Birthday today - aged 113.  He lives in Southern Japan and hopes to live another 10 years at least!

Would you like to live that long?  Sure, an instant reaction is 'yes, of course' but I gave it some thought and it frightened me when I thought that I could possibly have no husband, children of brothers/sisters and mother and father left.

I know age and death are a natural progression - but 113? Would you like to live that long?



</question>



<answer from>



Artemis
Member since: 01 November 2007
Total points: 4775 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Only if I was active and hadn't lost my marbles.



Lying in a bed dribbling all over the place is not something to look forward to.  My goodness wouldn't you be very tired by that age and had had enough.  Good luck to the old Japanese boy if he has the courage.



</answer>

As Gordon Brown appeared to be a decent chancellor of the exchequer (better than the current incumbent), it would reassure me.  As I understand it, the deal had to be done otherwise the crunch would've spiralled even further out of control.

If HBOS had gone to the wall, there would've been even more job losses.



It's a scary time, but i'm not sure what Mr Brown could've done !!!  He's not a great Prime Minister, but i'd still have him ahead of Cameron.



</answer>






<original file>index;_ylt=Ag2MnagFVzZXyYIRO9.Kb_EuLxVc86f.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk42306.txt</current file name>



<category>



News & Events



Current Events



</category>



<question from>



aDWsd
Member since: 15 September 2006
Total points: 94 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Question for people who know about the housing crisis?



In the past 15 years or so (maybe even longer), I remember hearing both Republicans and Democratics talk about how the government must increase the percentage of people who own homes. Does anyone know what programs the government had to allow people who could not otherwise afford a home buy one? Has anyone heard if these programs are believed to have had an effect on the mortgage crisis?



</question>



<answer from>



rhsaunde...
Member since: 07 March 2006
Total points: 189515 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



The government is most certainly involved.  Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, at the behest of Congress and particularly of Barney Frank, made or bought lots of loans made with little or no money down, and when housing prices failed to increase, a lot of these went into foreclosure.  Eventually, all of this will get worked out, but in the meantime getting a housing loan has become far more difficult.



</answer>



<answer from>



Gabe
Member since: 08 November 2006
Total points: 128 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



There were loans available during the last 5-7 years that didn't require a down payment to purchase a home.



There were loans available that allowed the seller to contribute up to 6% of the purchase price for the buyers "closing costs".  (Example: lets make a deal, want 6% MORE for your home?  I need closing costs paid...)



There were loans available that allowed more then 6 people to be on one loan, in order to purchase a home.



There were loans that allowed people to purchase a 2nd home (50miles away from your primary) with as little as 5% down payment.



There were loans that didn't ask for income documentation.  And lent 100% of the value of your home!



There were loans that lent 125% of the value of your home.



There were loans available for people with horrible credit scores 580 fico...but allowed a purchase qualifying on the interest only payment only.



There are loans still coming in the mail to all of us... Credit Cards, 90days no interests.  Debt keeps us going right?



Don't believe the hype.



The "mortgage crisis" is not the reason why we are ALL in this mess.  Our government has been "printing" way to much money long before the issue of "risky loans" came into play.



YOUTUBE: "Money as a debt"



Learn for yourself.



Source(s):



I was a mortgage banker for 5 years.



</answer>

<answer>



Capitalism is NOT failing; it is simply having the same sort of hiccups that it has had for the past 400 years, when Isaac Newton (not at all a foolish man) lost a pot of money in the South Sea Bubble.  In the 1920's, the bubble was stocks; in the 1990's it was dot-coms; in this decade, it has been real estate.  This has been exacerbated by Congressional pressure (particularly from Barney Frank) for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to make more and more risky loans.  That chicken has now come home to roost, and we are now well covered with chicken excrement.



</answer>

<answer>

They particularly don't want to know if you're an otherwise self-sufficient white native British taxpayer who's fallen on hard times (I was refused any help by the Council when I was 8 months pregnant and we were facing repossession, despite all the taxes me and my hubby have paid to them over the years and the fact that we've never asked them for help before, never even been on the dole!)

So you can forget that avenue.

The only option is to be royally ripped off by a private landlord.  And given that the rents these greedy bastards charge for their slums are pretty astronomical, thats pretty difficult as well.  Its just not do-able on minimum wage.  Even the grottiest bedsit will cost around £400 a month.  And on £5.52 an hour thats not possible if you want to eat and stay warm as well.

I think your children will be like most other young people and have to live at home until they're 30  . . .  Of course, you don't think this Government actually CARES do you?



</answer>



<answer from>



teddy
Member since: 10 July 2007
Total points: 39528 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



local councils won't help, as they are not homeless, how about a large shared house, many students do this to offset the costs. On the outskirts of London, you can rent property, inside the centre of London very difficult. A neighbour actually bought their children a flat, but that was absurd in my opinion, as it went for about £350,000.



very often info is available from the Uni, as people post stuff on Bulletin boards there, looking for people to share.



</answer>

<question>



Sneaky DVLA.............?



The DVLA reveals that it has secretly funded a project for car manufactures for the past 10 years.
The car makers installed black- box voice recorder to determine the circumstances of fatal accidents in the last 5 seconds in a crash.
In most areas of Britain,the last recorded words of the drivers in 65% of fatal crashes were,"oh no"
However,in Sunderland 93% of the final words were,"hold my can of Stella till i shake these cops off....."

<question>



Newbie Driver: why are drivers in cities soo impatient and inconsiderate ?



I have only been driving around on my own a few weeks after passing my test and have a very prominant 'P' plate on the back and front of my newly purchased 3rd hand car. But where as I rarely got tooted, honked, shouted at or fingered when cruising  around as a Learner Driver with 'L' plates, the 'P' plates seem to bring out the worst of inconsiderate and impatient behaviour from other drivers, especially in the city areas. Woe betide me if I remain at front on a red to amber light for more that 0.01 miliseconds, or get caught in a wrong lane and dare to indicate to change over !

Why are drivers in cities soo impatient and inconsiderate.

Source: a couple of weeks on the road.



</question>



<answer from>



The Kangarooster
Member since: 27 June 2008
Total points: 209 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



because they think they are more important than you



</answer>



<answer from>



Chris S
Member since: 24 August 2008
Total points: 239 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Busy busy busy.  All consumed by jobs and financial pressures.  Job pressures, family pressures, and jobs that take a lot out of them.

Drive knowing people are thinking of themselves primarily and therefore 'defensive' driving is true.



</answer>

<question>



The tories are 25% ahead can they still lose the next?



Election is sow up they can,t lose or can they?



</question>



<answer from>



sweetsue...
Member since: 12 October 2006
Total points: 2848 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi. Opinion polls arent always right. They take a snap-shot of people and therefore can not be relied upon to be accurate. It depends on the numbers of people polled and where the poll was taken. So to answer your question yes the Tories could still lose a general election.



</answer>



<answer from>



Flag J
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 196 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Since it depends on who wins in each riding, a party can win an overall majority of the popular vote, but not enough ridings to become a majority government.

For example, say there are 3 ridings and the results of the vote in each riding comes in as follows:

Riding 1: Conservatives 85%, Liberal 8%, NDP 7%
Riding 2: Conservatives 45%, Liberal 50%, NDP 5%
Riding 3: Conservatives 45%, Liberal 5%, NDP 50%

In the end the Conservatives would have far more combined votes than the other two, but each party still only has one seat.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tigon
Member since: 18 June 2008
Total points: 2738 (Level 4)

Nick N
Member since: 12 January 2008
Total points: 750 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



No they are not the same thing.



The credit crunch is when banks will not lend money, mainly because they don't have it or are scared the the people that they will lend it to will go bust and not pay it back.

A recession is when the economy is in decline for over 6 months. It is possible to have one without the other.



</answer>

<answer from>



powerser...
Member since: 29 September 2006
Total points: 547 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



No.  A recession has a generally accepted and precise definition.  A country is in recession when it experiences two successive quarters of negative growth - ie a falling GDP.

The 'credit crunch' is a recent moniker for the current cause of or current economic woes.  In recent years there had been far too ready a flow of cheap credit which was taken advantage of by major financial institutions to be able to offer incredible loans, mortgages deals etc.  It was however a bubble - effectively the money supply was bound to dry up at some Point, which it has done - hence the term 'credit crunch'.  The issue is that many major financial institutions over extended themselves offering products that were based entirely on the availability of cheap credit - and the taps shut off abruptly.  This isn't the same as a recession, but is a major causal factor.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer from>



dvapter
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 628 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



A recession is 'in the post'. Although the defn of a (cyclical) recession which periodically occurs in the capitalist economy has not yet been reached ie 2 consecutive periods of negative economic growth, its precursors are in place.
Panic and uncertainty in the international money markets possibly fuelled by predatory speculation against vulnerable banks with undercapitalisation/liquidity, has led to a restriction of credit and combined with high fuel/food prices hence to a decline in consumer spending, thence to a recession. This in turn leads to a rise in unemployment.
The next phase could be depression, which is much more long term and much more difficult to 'spend ur way out of' using monetary policy or indeed any alternative fiscal instrument.



Source(s):



just made it up 2 cheer u up!



</answer>

<question>



Should the Language of a country be prerequisite for leave to take up residence in that country ?



</question>



<additional details>



And who should bear the cost?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Michael ©
Member since: 04 October 2007
Total points: 29022 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Current Events



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



No but there should be an onus on that person to learn the language within say 18 months.

However the problem of foreigners living in 'ghettos' will remain.

Having lived in Spain (I speak Spanish) and Cyprus (slowly learning Greek) I can tell you that most ex-patriot British people tend to stick together and not even try to become fluent in the local language.

As for cost, I see no problem with making tuition available at a reasonable cost.

Personally I prefer the company of the local people, they are much more friendly and hospitable.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I love Cyprus and will be back there in a couple of weeks, And yes the people of Cyprus are really friendly. I also get by in Spanish and love mixing with the locals, had many a late night drinking and chatting in the local bars..



</asker's comment>

But definitely, basic knowledge of a language should be a requirement, it's common sense and would help the person to better integrate into the community.

Saying that though, and as many people have pointed out, few Brits would be abroad if that were the case. I was on holiday in France in August, and my neighbour there, who lived next to my rented holiday bungalow, was speaking very loudly in English to a waiter in a cafe who had trouble stringing two words together in English. Imagine the uproar if that happened here.



</answer>



<answer from>



Guy1
Member since: 08 June 2008
Total points: 617 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

Now i'm sorry but the needs of our elderly are paramount and the homes should only employ full English speaking people. Again, political correctness putting the elderly at the bottom of the list.

hitech.m...
Member since: 12 December 2005
Total points: 1160 (Level 3)

<answer>



First you have to know and understand who to sue.

There is a lot more here than meets the eye and astonishingly more than the American news media is saying.

First of all the loans sold for financing homes had to get money from somewhere and the source of this first stage has been recently revealed in the Chinese press. The Central bank of China has on hand, 30 TRILLION dollars worth of American Home loan bonds that were purchased through the like of middle men such as Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch.

The Bank of China bought this massive amount of bonds against the advice of more seasoned bankers and now they are stuck with $30,000,000,000,000 worth of paper certificates that will probably be worth zip tomorrow.

Now one must question why a central bank would buy this much from a single source. If you are suspicious that's ok because the answer lies in what the central bank of China is saying now, and that is they are blaming their American partners for " making them buy these bonds" . The truth is that no one made them buy anything. They bought these bonds because they made money on the side for their own bank accounts, in the form of bribes and payoffs. They call them ' "expedite fees and gifts" but the money ended up making them personally rich.

In the rush to sell the Chinese more paper, the American bankers ignored safety and good business sense by selling loans to people who would never be able to pay them back in order to generate the bonds to sell to the Chinese and other banks overseas. To say that this is unscrupulous is putting it mildly. The bankers were becoming rich and no matter what happens to the loans, well, they have their money so who cares.

The reason that our US Government has refused to back up the failure of Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch is because in doing so, they would be giving the money to the rest of the world. Quite personally, I could give a dam if the Central Bank of China looses money, they deserve it for having such stupid, short sighted, and greedy leaders.

The good thing is that America wins in the long run, we get a lot of banks with a lot of houses that will be going on sale for a very good price, compared to housing 3 years ago that was grossly overpriced because of Realtor greed, buyer panic, and Chinese financed easy money. Once all of this settles out you will find a small group of savvy Americans with a lot of money, retired because their firms are all bankrupt, property at more reasonable prices, and realistic loan terms from sound banks.

This "correction" was badly needed and has shaken the trees to get rid of some entrenched white collar thieves. Hopefully very few will be allowed back in the system.



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=AsDn6vMtBQEl.W.PmWE6GNIuLxV9080.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk47410.txt</current file name>



<category>



News & Events



Current Events



</category>



<question from>



Crazed D
Member since: 02 August 2008
Total points: 694 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What effect does the stock market really have?



Just how much of the economy is tied to the stock market?



</question>



<answer from>



amandare...
Member since: 10 December 2007
Total points: 7499 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Actually it affects a lot of people - whether or not you buy/sell/own shares.

A lot of the economic market is tied to the stock market - loans and mortgages are bundled and sold, bank assets are traded, the dollar is tied to the stock market.  Many institutions are invested in the stock market:  company pensions, universities, for-profit hospitals, banks - if the market drops, they have less money to fulfill their needs.  Banks can't lend money, universities have to charge more tuition to make up the difference, pensions lose value.



Most people who have 401K, IRAs or other retirement accounts are involved in the stock market

It is a giant f.... up



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Yes, it is.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Icarus
Member since: 25 January 2007
Total points: 3463 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's a big deal but it only hurts you personally if you sell shares.  Now is a really good time to buy shares.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mike B
Member since: 10 August 2007
Total points: 19818 (Level 6)



Contributing In:

tcw



</answer>
