<answer>



I think what you are doing wrong is to go by what things SEEM like.
I know people on disability and welfare and such and they are barely getting by. Sometimes there might be one family member on welfare and others working so don't let what things SEEM like become truth for you. 
Example: If you saw a guy standing over a dead body with a gun, it would SEEM like the guy with the gun was the killer. But this guy with a gun could be a cop, a busness owner who heard the shots, a kid with a realistic looking toy gun, a guy going to the pawn shop to pawn the gun or a citizen with a concealed weapon permit trying to help the guy who got shot etc etc.
A satellite dish on a house doesn't really prove anything, it doesn't even prove that the people living in that house have enough money to buy beer and cigs, or that they are long-term unemployed.
Now there are always other explanations for these types of appearances. It could be that all the people you know of who are out of work and have satellite dishes and who drink and smoke are meth or crack dealers, or it could be that for some strange reason you know thousands of long-term unemployed families of drunk people who smoke too much, or it could mean that you live with a family of long-term unemployed folks and they won't let you choose the staellite TV station and they aren't sharing their booze and smokes...so many possibilities, so few people who will just mind their own business.



Source(s):



Life, the Universe, and Everything

<answer>



If my daughter was 12/13, absolutely! Cervical cancer is a silent killer, displaying no symptoms until its too late. Cervical cancer caused 949 deaths in the UK in 2006. Your daughter will probably be sexually active at some point in her life (I know it's not something you like to think about, as a mother) and you should take full advantage of the opportunity for her to have the injection. I was not so lucky. I had cervical cancer at the age of 21 after the birth of my first baby. Luckily I was always one to have smear tests done regularly and caught it before it spread. I would really like my grumpy teen to have the injection, as cervical cancer has been present in my family previously, but I don't think its available to anyone outside of schools.



</answer>

<question>



Why does everyone succomon to fear and sell thier stocks when the media yells recession?



People panic and sell their stocks at low prices, because they think they are about to lose money, when that is exactly what causes companies to go under. On wall street, stocks fell DUE TO PEOPLE PANICING AND SELLING THEIR STOCKS because the media smears in the world face when a few companies go bankrupt.  I mean people are selling their stocks (and not buying like they should be) in companies that aren't doing bad, causing their stock prices to fall. Remember America, when you buy stocks at low prices, the company gains money, does better and people prosper. All the media hype on fannie mae and freddie mack, Lehman, and now the AIG scare, has caused ALOT of other companies to lose in the stock market because people are thinking OH MY GOD&lt; and selling even when they don't own stock in those companies. Doesn't everyone understand that "spending money on companies, buying stock, and buying their products is what makes those companies, and america's dollar value prosper. We had a natural disaster... Hurricane Ike, which yes, hurt oil prices due to the texas storm, however, now other countries are seeing everyone in American media yell... OH NO, recession,,,,, just because a couple of companies need help, thus selling thier stocks causing even more turmoil on wall street. America is prosperious because of the ability of businesses to prosper (small an large) however, when there is a "panic alert in the media, we get hurt even worse because people stop investing. Everyone needs loans to buy houses, supplies to build houses, and fix things in our current homes, food to eat, cars to get around, and what makes America so prosperious is the public (people) buying things to do this.  COmpanies are going under because people are in fear and not spending like they could. Gas prices hurt us, yes, but think of it this way...... It's only 2.00 more than 4 years, ago, if that, yet we will spend thousands of dollars on video games for our kids, eat a nice resturants, and buy non needed items-over needed ones, then complain about gas prices, Yet Americans can see that those three companies that failed is not what made America prosper... it's all the businesses, So why punish those companies and hurt our ecomony more buy selling their stocks when we should be taking advantage and buying more stocks now, while cheaper.... that alone would help our economy.



I'm just saying, think about it......... we panic....we sell....we all lose in the long run..........(i understand selling companies that are folding, but let's not make more fold by doing unnecessary things.) With all the media hype, You can bet, other countries are going to pull their shares out of our stocks, which will cause us to fail more, while we here are doing the same.... All because the media yells.... recession or some journalists writes a front page article sayong "worst recesion since 1930...  Well hell yeah, thank you, now it will be worse.



People, wake up, we can fix this problem, buy low...sell high! 
Not the other way around.



</question>

If stocks are low now..... BUY! They will go back up ya know, and I bet right after the election too!

But instead of people leaving them be, and waiting for them to go back up... they panic, and sell because they think that company can't regain when it can! Like I said..panic! It's not impossible...!

<answer>

<answer>

Smear tests will still be required, but most importantly, sexual health education will still be required.

Dellyxx

Total points: 6218 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Our kids always came in with spellings to learn - 5 or 6 words a week isn't difficult.  It makes them think, and makes them use their brain.



I remember picking my daughter up from her reception class (4 and 5 year olds) and a mother was checking her son's spellings.  He'd got 3 wrong and she was screaming like a banshee, telling him no telly, no playstation until he'd got them all right.  He was only 4.  The whole school heard her, the kid was really embarrased - the parent's attitude was all wrong on this occasion.



I think that the attitudes of schooling is the cause of the decline in the behaviour of our kids nowadays.



When I was at school, our teacher had a bag of sticky stars - if your work was good, you'd get a gold, silver or coloured star.  It was such an great feeling to get a star stuck in your jotter.  Nowadays, instead of testing them, praising them and giving them stars when they get things RIGHT, the ones who are a bit behind are being mollycoddled so that they don't feel left out and non achieving.  They're all treated the same so as not to offend.



Not good enough - if they're not achieving, they need to be told.  What's wrong with saying try harder and you'll get a star next time.  They need to know that the other kid got the star and that they have to WORK to get it for themselves.



And the kid who's done well should be praised.



</answer>

<answer>

</question>



<additional details>



Cardinal Folly - LOL, the breakdown of our society as you see it occured long before the 80's. Or was everything before then a bed of roses. Like when we had slavery and Hitler and World Wars and the Ku Klux Klan.



Oh but they were the good times. Its only now everything has gone bad .......... pffff.



</additional details>



<answer from>



ZACK NEEDS HELP, OR HERE TO HELP
Member since: 14 March 2008
Total points: 191 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Should the cane be reintroduced in schools to help discipline todays youth? Or is it a form of strange and inhumane punishment? Have your say...



During a wide-ranging discussion this week on why we, as a society, seem to be getting more violent and aggro, a lot of calls, emails and sms came in saying we should bring back the cane - reintroduce corporal punishment in schools.



Many listeners claimed that being caned at school taught kids of the time to respect - or at least fear - authority figures.



A lot of you also think getting the cane for breaking the rules provided students with a consequence for their actions that actually meant something - as opposed to detention, which is often seen as too 'soft'.



There does seem to be a growing support for the use of the cane when students are involved in incidents of violence. The argument is that if violence is the language being used by kids, then using similar 'language' as punishment is something violent students will understand.



But critics of corporal punishment in schools claim that teaching kids not to be violent by using violence - the cane - is not going to work.



Many parents also baulk at the notion their kids will be hit by teachers.



But it is possible these are the very parents whose kids lack any kind discipline at home.



For what it's worth, my parents always thought any caning I got - and there was some - was most likely thoroughly deserved. In other words, they left the school to make that determination. They trusted the school to make that judgement.



So what are the pros and cons of reintroducing corporal punishment?



And should that kind of punishment be handed out to both genders - boys and girls?



Because when I was at school, the cane was only for boys, and of course, the girls got away with murder because they knew the worst they would cop was a detention.



It's also worth pointing out this was a time when all girls were considered sweet and innocent, and that only boys could be really bad. We know today that is anything but true.



So would bringing the cane back to schools do any good to curb what is seen as a lack of respect and an absence of discipline in some young people these days?



Source(s):



http://blogs.triplem.com.au/triplem/arch...



</answer>

Member since: 17 December 2007
Total points: 2233 (Level 3)

The officers where right to fire and acted in a very courageous way.



All he had to do was stop and obey police commands, instead soon after attempted terrorism attacks he chose to ignore armed police.



and regarding shoot first and ask questions later there is a very good excuse that is the people who board buses trains and blow them and themselves up in an instant



shoot to kill is not nice but in circumstances in necessary



these officers acted in a courageous heroic fashion, its just a pity the person killed decided to ignore the police



the police did the right thing at the time, its easy to judge in hindsight, unfortunately officers in the front line against terrorism to not have the luxury of hindsight they are to busy risking their own life's for us



</answer>

<question from>



gilly g
Member since: 31 August 2007
Total points: 9654 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



What's the deal with Barrack Obama 'rickrolling'?



I just caught the end of a news story that said Barrack Obama has been rickrolling. Can anyone shed any light on this for me please?



</question>



<answer from>



qazaqi55...
Member since: 24 July 2007
Total points: 285 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Obama 'rickrolled' mccain.



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_TiQCJXpb...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Dartboar...
Member since: 25 July 2008
Total points: 597 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Rickrolling is an Internet meme involving the music video for the 1987 Rick Astley song "Never Gonna Give You Up". The meme is a bait and switch: a person provides a Web link they claim is relevant to the topic at hand, but the link actually takes the user to the Astley video.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rickrolling



</answer>



<answer from>



Evil_Min...
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 293 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



ahh yes, the classic youtube joke. Obama has been rickrolling? lol



</answer>



<answer from>



bert
Member since: 08 April 2006
Total points: 36774 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<question from>



Katkat - cloned Mum of two :)
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 1302 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Do you think that this would be unreasonable?



I know I'm posting this in here again because I think you're all very knowledgeable and I would like as many opinions as possible.



Again it's about my little boy's Dad.



My little boy's Dad is notoriously uncaring and terrible at keeping to contact arrangements. He hasn't seen him for 2 weeks now, and has no intention of doing so. He has missed 75% of contact, and chosen other things over seeing his son constantly.



I've now reached the end of my tether - he has changed him number, and the one number I do have he refuses to answer. I've been trying to get him to stick to a routine and he won't.



After trying to contact him for a week, I really cannot be doing with this anymore. For my son's sake - he needs stability that he just doesn't get from his Dad.



I want to tell him (via text so at least he has no choice but to hear me out) that if he doesn't contact me by tomorrow night to arrange to see the little one at the weekend then I will assume that he doesn't want to see him anymore - based on this and his past behaviour and therefore if he wants to make that decision, it's fine by me, but that has to be his FINAL decision. No second chances, no going back, and he won't be able to see him again until Finn is at an age where he can choose to see him.



Do you think that sending this message would be unreasonable?



</question>



<additional details>



Simm - his Dad is even worse than him, and his Mum not much better.



I've had his best mate talk to him (who happens to see him more) and various other people. It's in one ear out the other.



For reason's I don't want to go into, I am 100% that the court would rule a no-contact order, and I don't want that to happen.



I don't want to cut him out at all - I want HIM to make a decision now, not when little one understands (he's 18 months now). I'm hoping it will give him a kick up the bum more than anything else.



</additional details>

<answer>

Love is a verb not a noun.



He doesn't deserve that child. It's not fair that others on this site are in turmoil, desperate for access to their children and yet he who has it on a plate fcuks up.



It's the likes of him that ruin it for others.



I'd be inclined to drop all contact and wait until he comes crawling.Then state your terms.



My cousin had to go through the same scenario  were the Dad was so unreliable that when he did take the child out , the child would scream hysterically and not want to go with a 'stranger'. She stopped access because of the effect on her child. It went to court. An order was granted. He never , not ONCE kept to it.



EDIT-I'm sorry Kat but no Dad is better than a bad Dad.

Also, make sure you keep a copy yourself. If he doesn't want to keep in contact with the child, go to your lawyer and make it legal. Good luck.

<answer>



One of the hardest lessons I had to learn was that you cannot turn a man into a good father.  It doesn't work.  and although the courts will force you to let him see his child, they don't force him to visit, if he doesn't want to.
I would stand back, and not get so emotional about it, hard as that is.  Let him come and go, and encourage your son to treat the relationship as a light hearted one, and not as a deep, meaningful one.
It is a waste, but it is better for your son to have a little bit of a relationship than not one at all, or one in which there is recrimination and arguing.
Let go, step back.  One day your son will be taller than his father and will look him in the eye and ask the same questions you have just asked.  And it will be too late - your ex will have lost all those wonderful, vital years.

<answer>



Remember that, whatever you decide to do, you will be answerable to your son one day.



Although his dad is a bit of a deadbeat, it may still be in your son's interests to retain some contact.  It's rarely useful to stop this completely.  Perhaps negotiation is the key here?  If the boy's dad finds it so hard to keep to the commitment he makes, why not make it, say, once every two months?  It's not a lot, but it's some contact and it may be easier for the dad to adhere to.  You could agree a system whereby you text him a reminder a week beforehand.



Alternatively, it may be better to keep contact very casual so that your son doesn't get his hopes up.  This will be inconvenient for you at times, but if it keeps your son in touch with his dad it's worth it.  It may mean that his dad contacts you and asks to see his son, say, in the next day or so.  A pain and unreasonable, yes, but worth it.



Let the boy's dad be the one to formally withdraw contact so that you can't have it held against you in the future.  Keep any communications from him in case he lies about what happened when his son challenges him when he's older.



I know that dads like this are irresponsible, selfish and annoying, but most kids treasure contact with both parents and are surprisingly forgiving when they're little, so I wouldn't end all contact.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Kat, i feel for you. Stay strong girl. Finn is still tiny...and from what i know you are both Mum & Dad to him. Keep it that way. Don't push for his Dad meeting him. Let the space be. Explain in baby words to Finn about different families. Let him know that some Dads like his, love their babies but still have to learn how to show it. Keep it short. Just so he knows hes loved but knows that as long as he has you and his brother and the family that is contact with him, his world is complete. Don't set up meetings...only you & smallies will be dissappointed. Like you say, let the decision come from the Dad...in his time, if he wants it. If it doesn't happen Kat, honestly, you 3 are better off without it...If it does, its a bonus. The main thing is that Finn knows that he is loved and you will be a constant in his life. Kids are resilient...he will understand. Just make sure you shower him with all the love & attention he needs so hes secure with you. Then  he won't need anybody else. xxx

<answer>



I wouldn't be rushing to burn the communication bridge quite yet in spite of your ex's poor behavior.  You don't mention your little boy's age which is an important consideration in this situation.



I would recommend sending a registered letter (keep a copy) to your ex in which you outline your concerns without threatening him.  Men don't respond well to these threats, they just disappear.



My children's father did a geographic years ago and that certainly didn't solve any problems, it made them worse.  Take some more time and move on with your own life which is the best thing you can do for your son.



Incidentally, men freak if you change gears on them and stop communicating when they are used to being harangued all the time.



Source(s):



58 and it all worked out in the end with patience.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I would like to say that you trying contact him is too much effort on your part. Usually with unstable parents, you should take the attitude that he should call you if he wants to see his child. It's less frustration on your part, and less pressure for him (yes, deep down I think he feels bad about not being with his child, and his guilty conscience is kicking his bum).
I have gone threw this myself and with stepchildren. In my case, I used to just plan my activities for the week/ month/ year, and when he called to see them I either told him he could because I did not have plans, or he could not, because I had already a full schedule. If he is not agreeing and sticking to regular visitation, that's what he got (he's out of the picture now).
In my step-children's case, their Dad was a bit more lenient, he would change plans when she called (once a month or every other month), but the effect was the same as it was in my case, she slowly faded herself out of the picture.
I suggest ultimatums just gets tempers flaring and might get him to act right, but only short term. Let it be up to him to end contact; just protect yourself and stop bugging him.
You might want to get a consultation with a lawyer to see what your state law considers abandonment and what your right is as far as refusing contact . Most states would count it against you if you refuse to give him visitation (unless there is evidence that he is physically harming or neglecting your son when he is with him), but don't require you to actively seek it.
if you have an active custody agreement filed with the court and he violates it (by not showing) that could be considered abandonment. So, if you don't have one, you need to get one, for your protection.
i know this is a lot of info, sorry! Good luck!



Source(s):



If you wish you can add me to your contacts, if you want to follow up on this.



</answer>

<answer>



With the limited " one perspective" information provided..... it is difficult to judge BUT I would not send the message.... it will not produce the results you and your son want



FIRST Because you are threatening a consequence you can not enforce.... if he decides to see his son .....you can not stop him..... he will "win" again
SECOND This appears to be a battle of wills.....you tell him he will.....he is telling you (indirectly) he wont..... you can not.....without a lot of legal hassle.....impose your will upon him.... you are wasting your time trying to make him do the right thing



THIRD This war is "injuring" your son...... broken promises..... disappointments..... he may even blame himself for you both fighting



MY ADVISE..... Forget "Dad" (?) or expecting him to do right.... build a new loving life with your son.....quit expecting anything from "Dad"(?)
Do not share your anger or disappointment with your son.... Do not contact or expect anything from your ex-......



He knows what is right.....he knows he is wrong.... but each time he defies you; he wins..... use reverse psychology..... expect nothing..... ask for nothing.....



</answer>

<answer>



I don't think ultimatums ever work.  It will just give him a reason to feel aggrieved at your, in his eyes, unreasonable behaviour and he will be telling anyone who cares to listen what a cold b!tch you are to cut him off from his son.  I'm not saying he's right, but I'm guessing that's what he will do and I doubt you want that.



There's not a lot you can do really.  You've found yourself in a very difficult position by having a child (I thought you had two?) with a man who was not committed to you or your family and the best course of action is to just wait it out and live your life the way you want to.



Don't give him your time and energy and remember that success is the best revenge.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



My parents got divorced when I was 6 months. Father was unstable and always in and out, much like what you described. My father didn't put much effort to be stable, but when he did I appreciated it, even as a young child. If he came around he would take me and my sister to the Zoo, or Great America, and then we wouldn't hear from him for months, sometimes years. My mother was always very angry with him, she cried a lot and I know she went through hell because of him. But I am thankful that she never told him he wasn't allowed to see us (unless he was using again). Had there been a time that he was sober and wanted to see us and she forbade it, I would be resentful toward her. Epically since you have a boy, that's something he's going to need is his father in his life, he may resent you later if you don't allow his father to contact him.



I'm now 19, and my father got out of prison for the 2nd time last year, and I'm trying to keep in touch with him. We live in the same city, and I see him maybe once a month, but he seems to be doing better now that my sister and I are both over 18.



</answer>

<question from>



Omstarts

Total points: 344 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How likely is it that if I give my bank £50,000, Gordon Brown will guarantee it's safety?



Well firstly it ain't likely as I don't quite have £50,000 to spare.



I am talking about this 'promise' he has made to up the guarantee on savings held with British banks from the current FSA threshold of £35,000.



Does this help, and is it likely? Surely the potential liability to the government is colossal?



</question>



<answer from>



Albert R
Member since: 21 June 2007
Total points: 7624 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes it is colossal, but so is losing all your savings.  We vote for governments and their duty is to us and not to the banks.  The Irish government has gone further and guaranteed the lot.



</answer>



<answer from>



milftast...
Member since: 24 August 2007
Total points: 3392 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



open an Irish bank account, we'll mind it for you!!! =0)



</answer>



<answer from>



scullion
Member since: 20 November 2007
Total points: 3104 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your money is extremely likely to be safe.  Even without raising the threshold, no one in the UK has lost a penny of savings as a result of the banking crisis.



A guarantee of £50,000 is realistic and would have a reassuring effect which should mean the need to rely on it becomes even more remote.



If the UK government were to say it guaranteed 100% of all bank deposits, that would not be plausible so might well have less benefit overall than a £50,000 guarantee.



</answer>



<answer from>



daffadaf...
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 659 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The ceiling will be raised by the FSA to £50,000, by the end of next week.



It's a guarantee to bring back some confidence and stop people taking deposits out of banks.  If it helps restore confidence, then it is a good thing and will not cost anything to the taxpayer.  The cost of doing nothing is potentially far higher, if liquidity dries up and the recession deepens.



</answer>



<answer from>



kerryann...
Member since: 12 June 2007
Total points: 6171 (Level 5)

<answer>



Bad in what way?



A bad father?  Don't know.



A bad tennis player?  Don't care.



A bad prime minister?  Depends - much of what is going on is beyond his control whereas he at least has the background and confidence to know how to deal with it calmly and constructively.
A bad leader? Certainly not a charismatic leader.  Probably not a leader who might appeal to a soap-opera loving reality TV viewer or to a right-wing extremist.  If you like your leaders loud and in-your-face, he is not the man.



For me, his biggest failing is that he has to rely on the advice of 'high-flier' civil servants who are no better than the 'high-flier' bankers who have screwed us all so badly.  The dishonesty of the retrospective application of higher car tax of cars bought since 2001 was the killer.  He may be unexciting, but I always thought he was honest.



As it happens, I thought John Major was OK too.  Another leader who appealed to the intellect rather than the emotions.



</answer>

<question from>



Is everything a Violation on Y!A

<question>



Did you hear about the 7 year old who went on a killing spree?



How does someone not know where they 7 year old is?  I admit it is kind of funny.  http://www.wave3.com/global/story.asp?s=...



SYDNEY, Australia (AP) - Zoo officials in Australia are planning to sue the parents of a 7-year-old boy who broke into a popular Outback zoo and fed animals to a giant crocodile.



Zoo director Rex Neindorf says the boy jumped a security fence, then went on a 30-minute killing spree, bashing several lizards to death with a rock and feeding them to a 440-pound saltwater crocodile. The boy also threw several live animals over the fences surrounding the crocodile's enclosure.



Neindorf says on the zoo's security camera, the boy's face remains largely blank, "like he was playing a game."



The 13 animals killed are worth more than $5,000. Police say they're unable to press charges because of the boy's age.



</question>

SYDNEY, Australia (AP) - Zoo officials in Australia are planning to sue the parents of a 7-year-old boy who broke into a popular Outback zoo and fed animals to a giant crocodile.



Zoo director Rex Neindorf says the boy jumped a security fence, then went on a 30-minute killing spree, bashing several lizards to death with a rock and feeding them to a 440-pound saltwater crocodile. The boy also threw several live animals over the fences surrounding the crocodile's enclosure.



Neindorf says on the zoo's security camera, the boy's face remains largely blank, "like he was playing a game."



The 13 animals killed are worth more than $5,000. Police say they're unable to press charges because of the boy's age.

<answer from>



Pete

<answer>



Frankly, both sides are idiots.
It's tit for tat attacks backwards and forwards.
It's East vs West.
And Depending on if the US are terrorists only is determined by what side your on. If you are with Al-Qaeda, then the US are terrorists whilst Al-Qaeda are freedom fighters. Otherwise it's Al-Qaeda are terrorists and the US are counter-terrorists.



The War on Terror will never really be accomplished (much like the US War on Drugs) It's just a political label so that the US citizens believe the government are doing something. This benefits the government by investing in military and allows legislation to change regarding the investigation of suspects.



All in all, the label terrorism is one that does not have a universal meaning and is basically only used to stigmatize and prosecute people.



Source(s):



Studied Terrorism in University.



</answer>

<question>



Anyone really believe this bailout/rescue will fix the problem?



my thoughts...
...D''oh!...
Come on peeps we all knew it would never work...
Think back, why were people buying up fancy cars and second homes? because the value of their first home skyrocketed, so they refinanced used the equity in their homes to go buy all those fancy toys...
now that market has crashed the moneys dried up. homeowners are stuck with a 400k loan and a house worth around 150k.



just because you free up credit people will still walk away which makes perfect economic sense to a struggling family! They already took the money now its time to run!
Fund managers are already looking to foreign markets to invest our tax dollars in, and for good reason. we make nothing in our country, wages are a joke when compared to cost of living.the line between rich and poor grows wider everyday. Forget middle-class even they find themselves bordering on working poor or about to join the ranks of the jobless!



Lets say you pass this bill? how long will it take the market to turn around, 3, 4 months? Half a year is more likely, in which time we lose another 2 million homes to forecloses. Come on  lets be realistic here this proposal fixes noting, not in time at least!



what do you think?

<question from>



Setanta Boru ~O My Brothers
Member since: 09 October 2008
Total points: 1298 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Current Events



</question from>



<question>



Should all drugs be legalised?



7 out of 10 people in prison are there for drugs offences
those who get out find getting a job difficult with a criminal conviction



legalising drugs would provide employment and tax money instead of now where drugs pay for gangs, people trafficking and terrorism.



it would also free up the police to investigate real crimes, if people are going to take drugs then thats their choice, even though they are currently illegal its very easy to get any drug you want.



so should drugs be legalised?



</question>



<answer from>



Brassy
Member since: 26 August 2007
Total points: 390 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Remember what happened during prohibition? Crime, violent crime rose. People were gunned down in the streets, massacred in clubs, and gangs ruled whole areas. People in the country were making it in the woods behind their homes, in their basements, and sometimes in their bathrooms. People died from explosions, and the wrong mixture of ingredients.



Sound familiar?



Why are we being saved from ourselves? We can't legislate human vice. We've fought the war on drugs for decades and have only succeeded in spending too much money on something that's never going to happen.



If a woman has a choice on what to do with her body why can't all humans have the same choice?



Legalize all drugs, monitor it, tax it, create jobs and revenue! That will give organized crime and gangs one less thing to fight about.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



great answer thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Smutty
Member since: 25 June 2006
Total points: 1656 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Some should I think, But the problem is that people do things to the extreme. If drugs were legalized, then more people would be trying them and more people would be addicted to them and more people would end up dying because of them themselves or killing others because of them.



Alcohol and tobacco products are legalized and provide a good tax revenue, but how many people die each year or become addicted to alcohol and tobacco products?



How many die from cancer or liver damage or other diseases and sicknesses related to those legalized products? Way too many.



It's unfortunate because some people can control themselves and act intelligently and safely and take things in moderation. It's the one's who can't control themselves and don't act intelligently or safe that ruin it for the rest of us and make it dangerous to all of us.



</answer>



<answer from>



T splatter
Member since: 11 July 2008
Total points: 1323 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



this is usually a argument raised by users drug addition is high and there have been arguments and studies such as in amsterdam where the drugs were legalised.



The crime rate etc was just as high and also there is still prostitution and gangs and still the "black" market just as there is with gambling.



It may be easy to get the drugs however will it change or will everyone just be off their nut if they are legal.



However i can see your argument about people entering the "justice" system by simple possession.  There have been certain areas where it has been decriminalised.



Source(s):



http://www.pubclub.com/amsterdam/coffeeh...



</answer>

Member since: 07 May 2007

<answer>



Well, if it is the question of space in prison and money for police I say lets do away with all laws and that way we wouldn't have to have ANY jails or prisons, no tax dollars need to be spent on police forces and you could prove your grit by being responsible for your own families safety.



The argument for legalizing drugs is nothing more than a cry from users to decriminalize THEIR habit.



Same for any abusive crime, they want their personal habit legalized and Damn the public.



</answer>



<answer from>



Neil
Member since: 16 November 2006
Total points: 6405 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think its obvious the present drug law is not working.



Drugs is the major cause of crime in this country, druggies stealing to fund a habit.



My gut reaction is to make the laws stricter, Life sentences for drug dealers, 3 strikes and you are out for addicts. Offer two chances of good treatment, if that fails, third time lock them up and throw away the key.



The other option as you suggest is decriminalisation. Studies have shown that some addicts can function on drugs like heroin, but what message are we giving to kids. OK we might take the drug trade out of the hands of criminals but in the eyes of many we would be 'legitimising' drugs.



I don't think either way would make much difference but if I had to choose I would go for clamping down very hard on drug dealers and users.



</answer>

Member since: 01 April 2008
Total points: 3367 (Level 4)

<question from>



Thorn

</question from>



<question>



Does anyone else hear the booming that is going on near the DFW airport?



It is a really low frequency and is causing the ground to shake.  It's almost like an earthquake...but only one boom at a time.  The Euless Police admitted that they are being flooded with calls, but no one knows what it is.  I really hope it is not the natural gas drilling.  (It sounds a little bit like the creature from Cloverfield when it was walking.)



</question>



<additional details>



DFW is the airport in Dallas/Fort Worth Texas.  Euless is right next to it...though I have some friends in Bedford who just called to say that they feel the booming too.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Chris
Member since: 01 December 2006
Total points: 323 (Level 2)

<answer from>



Tabatha S
Member since: 04 June 2008
Total points: 253 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Thai Green Curry with Beef
This Green Curry recipe features beef but could also be prepared with chicken, pork or fish. If sweet basil leaves are not available, you may substitute European basil, or leave it out altogether. You can serve this dish accompanied with a cooling soup, like Glass Noodle Soup (Gaeng Joot), stir-fry or steamed vegetables, and of course steamed jasmine rice.



Ingredients
400 grams beef (a little less then 1lb.)



3 tbsp green curry paste (see green curry paste recipe or use prepared curry paste)



2 1/2 cups coconut milk (1 1/2 cans Chaokoh brand coconut milk or squeezed out from 400 grams grated fresh coconut)



5 small fresh Thai eggplants, quartered



2-3 fresh red spur chilies, sliced diagonally



2 kaffir lime leaves, torn



1/4 cup sweet basil leaf (optional)



1 1/2 tbsp fish sauce



1 1/2 tsp palm sugar



1 tbsp cooking oil (not olive oil, but corn, safflower or peanut oil)



Sweet basil leaves and red chili slices for garnish



Preparation



Slice the beef into thin pieces, about about 1/3" (3 cm) thick.



Saute the green curry paste in oil over medium heat until fragrant, reduce the heat, gradually add 1 1/2 cups of the coconut milk a little at a time, stir until a film of green oil surfaces.



Add the beef and kaffir lime leaves, continue cooking for 3 minutes until fragrant and the beef is cooked through. Transfer to a pot, place over medium heat and cook until boiling. Add the remaining coconut milk, season with palm sugar and fish sauce. When the mixture returns to the boil add the eggplants. Cook until the eggplants are done, sprinkle sweet basil leaves and red chilies over, then turn off the heat.



Arrange on a serving dish and garnish with sweet basil leaves and red chilies before serving.



Enjoy!



</answer>

<question from>



WeepingW...
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 708 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How can the future be predicted when it hasn't happened yet? ?



</question>



<answer from>



Skytale
Member since: 03 June 2006
Total points: 774 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



When you see a wave coming towards shore, you can predict that it will keep rolling till it fades on the sand.  When you place a tasty bit of food in your mouth you can predict that you will swallow it and down it goes to your stomach.  One prediction is based on knowing the laws of the world and the other from knowing yourself.  Events are interactions, and predictability, that is, a fairly reliable one, depends on the knowledge held about what has previously occurred, and also on the understanding of how things work.



We can predict where the moon will be in the sky centuries from now because we know that the moon is affected by the laws elaborated by Newton, laws based on insight and statistics.  If we did not apply these laws, then we would only be guessing.  Predictions that are based on past behaviours and on evidence presently known, are not the same as certainties, but they have a better record than guesses do.  Guesses are wild stabs, that may be right, but have not been researched or reasoned out.



Predictions are reasonings from prior realities (or should be).  A prediction that you doubt, is not a prediction, it is a 'maybe'.  The worth of a prediction lies in its links to reality and to known past happenings.



Astounding predictions that are based on the opinion of a person or non-scientific book, are not necessarily predictions but may be Prophesies.  For the multitude of prophesies that have been recorded throughout time, their record of correctness has been rather poor.  It is often only after a prophesy seems not to have eventuated, that a dispute arises by the originators or backers of the prophesy, as to what the prophesy actually meant to say.  Predictions, although maybe not very detailed, should be clear enough to be able to later determine whether or not they actually did occur, without a dispute muddying the waters.



Future events many not have happened as yet, however, the events leading up to them have happened and are happening now.  The scientific laws that govern certain events are only known by their presence in the past and by their validity right now.  Therefore, any event dependent on such laws is not a separate thing but simply a continuity, a convergence of all that is before its time.



Predictions are not meant to be certainties because there are other equally valid events or entities that may interfere with what may be reasonably expected.  A submarine may fire a torpedo at a ship but the torpedo may malfunction.  The known statistics on malfunctions of whatever is utilised, item and environment, can be used to gauge the Probability of a hit.  If a whale gets in the way of the torpedo then that is an example of an unexpected interference.  We can only hope that what we do is for the best to make an event occur, and know that there are others, such as the passengers on the ship, who hope otherwise.



We know and can in some ways predict the future, because any future is not its own master but depends up all that precedes it.  The Future is Especially dependent on the present events that immediately precede it in the 'now'.  If you want to change the Future you simply need to change the Now that activates it (activists please note).



</answer>



<asker's comment>



ty



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Super Team

Total points: 499 (Level 2)

</answer>

<question from>



paradoxi...
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 932 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What is up with Biden? ?



Did Biden say that the U.S. will be attacked when Obama is elected to say that the media/american influence will not criticize Obama when something will happen? They know allot more than we do about U.S. intelligence of foreign threats to the U.S., and he therefore is trying to cover the track when Obama does not instill world peace with the U.S. at the helm?

</question>



<answer from>



Obama wants to delay discovery
Member since: 14 August 2006
Total points: 3311 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>

<question>



Do you think that the USA will expand the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan to include Syria and Pakistan?



The USA has been launching varying kinds of attacks against Taliban and other groups in those countries recently. The countries involved are protesting loudly. Pakistan has had to suffer repeated attacks. Syria's borders have been less often violated.



Obama, McCain and Bush don't seem to be very different on this issue, except that Obama seems to be more concrete in his plans to leave Iraq. About Pakistan, he has been, if anything, the most aggressive of the three in his rhetoric.



So, this isn't really an election issue. It just is an incredibly important, vital issue!



</question>

He suggests it would set a superb example if clubs agreed to pay their low-paid workers -- shop assistants, catering staff and cleaners -- the London living wage.

Have you ever heard of "mischief" night?

<answer from>



Megan
Member since: 21 January 2008
Total points: 1354 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't know about Widnes, but I do know about Mischief Night. It is a night where a lot of trouble happens at night. Most people in my town, wont leave their animals out for long tonight and bring in some of their decorations.



When I was a junior in high school, our powder puff football game was held on Oct 30th in hopes to stop some of the occurrences of Mischief Night. This was first started in 2003, so 5 years ago, and the game is still held every year on the 30th.



When I was younger, like 9 or 10, I was with my sister on Mischief Night and the cops stopped us because there was a lot of vandalizing going on and they wanted to know if we had anything to do with it.



I think it only takes place in small towns.



</answer>



<answer from>



pinkstar...
Member since: 06 November 2007
Total points: 1626 (Level 3)



</answer from>

Robbie

Total points: 1373 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



No.  To my mind whilst there are problems with the benefits system and its abuse it is not this that has caused the recession and the deep economic problems.  The problem is the lack of borrowing now available which affects all businesses as people can't borrow money to purchase goods and businesses can't borrow money to expand and diversify.  Therefore if the minimum wage were to be increased this would create even greater expense to businesses at a time when those businesses are making less money.  Therefore there would have to be cuts and unemployment levels would increase.



Good question though.



</answer>



<answer from>



The Incredible Sulk
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 156 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not necessarily, if the minimum wage increases it means (-) firms have decreased profits and subsequently less for investment. It would (+) give purchasers more disposable income but (-) they may invest in savings and the economy would not benefit from it at all.



I can see where you are coming from, because increased spending does increase overall economic growth and welfare in the long-term. The the tools which are used to do this are primarily the fiscal (concerned with taxes) and monetary (concerned with the money supply) policies.



Prices are being lowered to encourage consumers to spend more (following the main fundamental principle of economics - supply and demand). It seems to be working in the UK moreso than in America at the moment. Hopefully it will all work out okay.



PS. Don't be discouraged that everyone said that it wouldn't, it was good that you were curious and asked in the first place.



</answer>



<answer from>



proud walker
Member since: 19 August 2006
Total points: 21797 (Level 6)

<answer from>



MonaLisa Overdrive AM VT wannabe
Member since: 16 January 2008
Total points: 12941 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The obvious argument against is that it will mean fewer minimum wage jobs, and/or higher prices.  However, every single time the minimum wage has been increased, there has NEVER been an adverse impact on employment or inflation.  Never.



However, a single minimum wage everywhere makes no sense.  For any non-minimum wage job, people get paid more in expensive places to live, like the major cities, and less in inexpensive places to live.  There should be a higher minimum wage in New York City than there is in Des Moines, Iowa.  It just makes sense.



</answer>






<original file>13076.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk86724.txt</current file name>




<category>



News & Events



Current Events



</category>



<question from>



Jake S
Member since: 26 August 2008
Total points: 85 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why do people think that offshore drilling is helping to lower gas prices?



Oil companies are actually producing less oil because prices are down.  Prices drop when demand goes down or supply goes up.  In this case, demand has fallen way off because of fear of an economic recession.  Oil companies are trying to increase the demand by decreasing supply so they can keep their record profits.



</question>



<answer from>



Jeffrey S
Member since: 18 October 2006
Total points: 4445 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Current Events



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



No, oil companies are not "producing less oil because prices are down."  Supply and demand are not the only reason prices go up and down.  When you see such a tremendous increase in the price of a commodity in such a relatively short time, as you have with oil over the last few years, it is almost always due to speculation on that commodity, in this case oil futures.  The proof of this is in the fact that the price of oil has dropped precipitously over the last several weeks in concert with the stock market.  Many people have been getting out of the speculation business recently, and the oil futures market is no exception.



As for why some people think that drilling will have an effect on prices of oil and/or gasoline, it's because they don't understand how the oil business works.  I work for a major oil company, and I can tell you that even if all the restricted areas in the US were opened up to drilling tomorrow it would be years before any oil could be produced from them, particularly the offshore areas.  Even then, the amount of oil in those areas is small compared with total world production, which is the basis upon which oil is valued.  So there would be no effect at all on the price of oil and, by extension, gasoline in the short term, and little, if any, in the long term.



However, it is also true that the oil companies could make money drilling in those areas, lots of it.  I plan to retire in a few years, so the higher my company's stock is the better for me.  So by all means, "drill, baby, drill."  But unless you own oil company stock, it isn't going to make any difference to you.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



"OPEC said at an emergency meeting Friday that it will slash oil production by 1.5 million barrels to stem the "dramatic collapse" of oil prices, but crude prices plunged 7 percent anyway as financial markets spiraled downward across the globe."



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Beejee
Member since: 23 December 2005
Total points: 22375 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Off-shore drilling advocates hope it will help bridge the gap between our present dependence upon Mid East oil  and the ideal of total independence thereon.
It is to be hoped, also, that they factor-in the necessary companion policies that include other alternatives such as stricter mpg rules that automakers are begining to  shoot for and alternate energy sources like nuclear, solar, geothermal and wind.



It should be pointed out that 'T-Bone's' plea is about CNG, compressed natural gas



Source(s):



CNN



</answer>



<answer from>



Lincoln6
Member since: 27 December 2006
Total points: 28577 (Level 7)



</answer from>

<answer>

</answer>

<answer from>



Twiggy
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 127 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think they are lazy at all! Just because these illnesses don't have any obvious physical symptoms at first (e.g. a limp or something), it doesn't mean that there's nothing wrong with them! They are real illnesses with real, scientific consequences on the sufferer.



And as for people with these illnesses being "lazy", well you obviously have a warped, biased view of sufferers as people who just mope around and do nothing, being self-pitying. Though there must be some people like this otherwise this stereotype wouldn't exist in the first place, I know of several people who have suffered from depression and have continued with their jobs, looking after their children etc.



Even the people who do give up their jobs etc DO have reason for it - they're not being self-pitying, theyre suffering heavily from an illness. Just because the sufferer does no have a broken leg or similar, and instead has a mental illness, does not mean they are any less deserving of help or time off from work etc.



If this does not help explain mental illnesses a bit further, please do some research - I'm sure you'll find scientific proof that depression etc sufferers are not merely being "lazy".



</answer>



<answer from>



Deman Within
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 129 (Level 1)

<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>

Health care reform is THE big one; new tax codes without excessive burdens on the middle class; moving ahead with science and technology regarding alternative energy sources; new forceful regulations on banking and finance; other environmental issues, like more recycling.  Repeal of NAFTA; immigration reform, higher standards for imports from China.  Many people want the war in Iraq ended immediately.  I don't think that will happen, but I'm not in charge of anything important, anyway...



Source(s):



A Voter.



</answer>

<answer>



Only a tiny minority of loud mouths are against Woss and Brand.



This is England where we have many hundreds of years of at the edge comedy, mostly of the lavatorial and morgue kind.



Here's a vulgar English joke from the 1930s.



Max Millar
"I was walking along this narrow moutain path when around the corner came a pretty young girl.  The path was too narrow for us to pass each  other, so I wondered whether to block her passage or toss my self off."



It's just a load of inuendo and it's all in the mind.



British and thus English humour is all about death, sex and the lavatory.



Here's one our finest comedians ever.  Oh, so roood!
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7FBVCIYB5...



This country is now one big CENSORSHIP and no longer looks like the England of my youth, born 1941, so I've heard most of them, they just get revamped and keep on going round.



If you're a Londoner like me, you'll appreciate the mildly cruel joke.  There you are walking along the road and you see a mate waiting at the bus stop.  You nod as you approach' awite? etc.  Then as you get closer you say to him, "no point in waiting there mate, they're on strike".  Of course you know perfectly well that they buses are not on strike, but your mate is now wondering whether to return home or walk to work.



Cruel.



</answer>

<question from>



Rino M
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 71 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What do you think of the right-wing Italian prime minister who took away money from Public schools....?



.... and increased the funds of Private schools and universities? This new reform also restores one unique teacher in the elementary schools and imposes elementary school students to wear uniforms. This changes things as Italians knew them before, when there were different teachers for different subjects and wearing a uniform was not mandatory.



The main concern of these protesters is the fact that it will increase the difference between public schools, where only poor people will go to the public schools and public schools teachers' wages will be lower, and private schools, which will create an elite group of students on the basis of their personal richness. Italy does not have a student loan program funded by the government as the United States does.



Proponents of this reform believe that this reform is right because it is something that comes from good sense and it will improve the quality of the schools.



800.000 Italians went out to protest in Rome last week. You can see what they did on here. You don't really need to listen to what they say, but just see how they protested. 800.000 people are almost 1/50 of the total Italian population that went to protest.



http://tg24.sky.it/tg24/cronaca/scuola_u...



</question>

They just jumped on the hyped up media band wagon. Sad representations of the British public. Know the facts before complaining!



Baillie slept with Brand and dances for a group called the Satanic Sl*ts(!) perhaps she should look at herself before complaining about others.



Also apparently the show was pre-recorded so if anyone is to 'blame' it's the producers/BBC bosses!



</answer>

<answer from>



Kit Fang
Member since: 12 February 2007
Total points: 7088 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think he should have been suspended. For God's sake people, it was a ******* joke. Most comedians have material like this, it just doesn't get aired - the editors should have been suspended, not Ross.



Everyone's always like "I'm paying my licence fee, I don't want it to be spent on Brand's show..." blah blah - I pay my licence fee, and I object to it being spent on the antiques roadshow, or this little dorrit (the book is almost as bad as something by jane austin) rubbish, but you have the right to watch it if you want to.



We are all born with a little thing called free will - if you don't like it, don't watch, and don't go onto youtube after reading about it in the daily mail, and then complain.



His ratings will be huge when he returns, and wherever Brand goes, he'll get huge ratings too. Ross' show would have been a lot better than whatever rubbish the BBC is replacing his show with this Friday, and Brand's pod cast was the most popular ever for a reason...



Get off the bandwagon and get over it. It happened weeks ago, and there are far more important things going on in the world. Get some perspective, and sense of humour, and a life.



</answer>

I ask You to raise up the president of Your choosing this year. You have been so faithful and true to us, God.  May Your will continue to be revealed to us through those who are elected this year.  In Your Holy name, Amen.

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hi all...



I'm wondering why there were no witnesses to see a 7 year old (probably kicking and screaming) coming from the house. I think, he was taken from the scene from someone he was familiar with and put in the white SUV. From there, maybe Balfour went in the house and did the slaying. But here's a crazy blog that I found (didn't write so don't get on my case).

So & So wrote...
&gt; I have 2 theories. One surrounds Julia, the other, Jason. For those of you who have blinders on and want to treat Julia like the innocent victim- fine with me. However, as far as I'm concerned there were three victims and they're no longer here to tell their stories. The most defenseless victim, Julian, a poor little 7 year old boy who suffered the most unimaginable fate, witnessed the brutal killings of his grandmother and uncle before being shot twice in the head. We must fight for this child and if this means by exposing his mother- then so be it. I come from a realistic world where unfortunately, mothers sometimes murder their children or contribute to their demise. This is my opinion and if you're one of those people who live in untainted worlds, I ask you to move to the next post because this will probably upset you.
&gt; Theory 1: Julia Hudson's Involvement
&gt; There are t oo many holes in this story:
&gt; 1)The body of Jennifer Hudson¢s mother Darnell Donerson was found by Jennifer Hudson¢s sister Julia around 2:45 PM Friday. Julia called 911 to report the shooting. She also reported her 7-year-old son missing. Police arriving on the scene found Hudson¢s brother Jason shot to death in a bedroom.- okay I got this from CNN. My question is how could she report her son missing if she never went through the house. She claimed to have walked in the door, and after seeing her mother's body in the living room, left out the house and called 911. She then went to the police station to report Julian missing. How did she know he was missing and not hiding in the house or somewhere murdered in the home? Apparently, the police discovered her brothers body- she did not. As I said, she only made it to the front door.
&gt; 2)Friday was a teacher's work day in Chicago. Therefore, children did not report. Julia is a school bus driver. Why was she working then? If her son didn't have school, she shouldn't have had to work. All Chicago schools are basically charter schools. Another caveat: How did she get home if Jason was her ride?
&gt; 3)Police have stated that Jason Hudson was shot when the gunman shot through the front door. He also received defensive wounds. However, his body was found in an upstairs bedroom. If you've seen a picture of him- he was no small guy. William, a man of small stature, could not have taken him upstairs alone. If Jason was shot in the thigh, he would have needed a very large person to help him upstairs. I always wondered in that type of area, shouldn't they have a gun in the home?



&gt; 4)Shell casings were found in Julian King's bedroom, yet police are saying he was killed in the SUV.
&gt; 5) The small bullet only went through the wooden door, so the door should have still been locked. How did the killer get in? If he shot at the door first, who in their right mind would have opened it for him?
&gt; 6)Why didn't they come at night when most murders occur? The whole family would've been there, and they could've killed everyone.
&gt; 7)Sure, the police could've been monitoring Julia's myspace, but I doubt it. This is more along the lines of the FBI and they didn't jump aboard until late Saturday. I'm sorry, but I just can't imagine with your mother and brother being tragically killed, and your son missing, the last thing I'd be thinking about is the damn computer. The BBC have a mandate gifted by the majority, a majority who are plagued by exactly the type of yobs that this broadcast was designed to appeal to, and their message is "you can have some rope, but don't mess".
The frankly, unfunny, Ross and the deeply unpleasant Brand, would do well to acknowledge.....I think they will.



</answer>

<question from>



LBJ
Member since: 03 March 2008
Total points: 6398 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



My real Q is why should women be in the clergy?



sorry about the last Q I just got a little vehemently angry at the thought.
We have nuns can't they understand that the divine doesn't want them as preachers or am I missing the point, all views accepted just keep the language down. thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



The Pirate Duchess ~
Member since: 30 August 2008
Total points: 2446 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Current Events



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I quite like The Vicar of Dibley....



</answer>



<asker's comment>



nononnonono ay yes. Right must cut back on the cognac its having some serious side effects.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



old know all
Member since: 13 April 2006
Total points: 54723 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



The Christian church has had women preachers from the earliest of days.  In certain circumstances, the Catholic, Orthodox and Armenian churches have women ministers of the Eucharist.  What they don't have is women priests.  That's something we have managed without for 2,000 years and if we're going to change it, it will be when everyone has agreed, not because it's fashionable for jobs to be non-gender-specific.



Many theologians can see no theological objection, although that doesn't mean they think it should be imposed.  The top brass in the Catholic church has decided - for now - that it does not have the authority to ordain women.  It's likely to stay that way until the current clique has died out.  The Orthodox are not in a position to entertain the idea.



Protestant churches do not believe in a separate priesthood.  They are not of the opinion that their ministers are part of a universal priesthood.



The problems facing the C of E is that they have one foot in each camp.  They claim to be both catholic and reformed.  If they are a protestant sect, they can do what they like.  If they are part of a universal church, they should not have acted unilaterally.



</answer>



<answer from>



steffi
Member since: 23 August 2007
Total points: 19707 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



United Kingdom



</answer from>



<answer>



The only reason why women don't have much of a history as priests is that it was a man-decreed thing, men have had financial  and government dominance for centuries. In the UK, at one time, a man gained all his wife's assets on marriage, she was his chattel. It is only recently that women had rights as independent people for income tax. Even their tax allowance, the Wife's Earned Income Allowance, belonged to the husband.
How do you know the divine doesn't want them as preachers? Been told personally? All religious doctrine is man-made and interpreted. It is our choice whether or not we accept it or question it.
I have always thought that religion is a living thing. If it is not, it will die. Therefore, at times, changes have to take place. How do you square the difference between the Old and New Testaments? One contradictory point is "an eye for an eye" (Moses) and "turn the other cheek" (Jesus). So which is right? Do you not think that religious instruction has to take into account cultural differences due to mankind's evolution?
There is such a problem recruiting priests these days that I think we have to be grateful that anyone is prepared to take on this difficult job, whether it be men or women, and I have to say that I think this job is more suited to women, who are known to be more sympathetic and understanding of life's problems.



</answer>
